Given the process oriented nature of the project it would not always be possible to schedule project activities along a critical path much in advance of implementation. Nevertheless, in view of the involvement of a number of agencies in project implementation, and the need to introduce adjustments regularly based on implementation experience, the project would establish a CPM system to assist with planning and timely execution of project activities. The CPM would have a detailed work breakdown structure in which tasks would be scheduled over the life of the project and grouped according to the various participating agencies that would be responsible for implementing them. Each of these agencies would be involved in determining the likely implementation schedule. The CPM would permit milestones and targets to be established for each of the project tasks in terms of work completed, disbursements, or time expended. Real progress would be tracked against projected progress and delays and bottlenecks identified promptly. 4.18 Annual Action Plans. Action plans would be developed from the CPM. These would be adjusted as required to reflect actual field experience and progress as indicated by the concurrent monitoring and evaluation and by the proceedings of annual reviews and workshops. These plans would provide details of all the tasks to be undertaken during the year including timing, manpower and financial resources and expected outcomes. To ensure that the project remains responsive to the needs of SHG members, the Annual Action Plans would be revised in mid-year in the light of specific requests for assistance expressed by the SHGs. The computerised MIS would provide the data base for monitoring project performance and the essential inputs for the CPM. It will enable quick and timely identification of groups facing unsatisfactory savings, lending and repayment rates at the field level, as well as other information on group functioning and sustainability. It will also, on a regular basis, evaluate the overall financial performance of the project and monitor its evolution. In addition, it would provide information to the CPM on a continuing basis on problems in the availability of resources required to implement the project and thereby assist in avoiding significant delays in implementation. 4.20 Concurrent Monitoring & Evaluation. The prime task of the state monitoring teams would be to visit the field and interview the staff of the various implementing agencies and beneficiaries to develop an objective view of the progress that is being made, problems and constraints confronted, and whether or not the project goals are being achieved. Participatory monitoring and evaluation methods would be used so that SHG members can assess their own progress, e.g., in group functioning, in tracking the impacts of their actions in the family, group and community, and revise their strategies accordingly. The implementing NGOs would be instrumental in guiding the SHGs in these processes. Concurrent monitoring would be carried out every quarter and a monitoring report issued following every assessment. These reports would be discussed with senior WDC staff and World Bank supervision missions. The lead agency would review the monitoring reports from the participating states on a six-monthly basis to enable inter- state comparisons of project performance and to ensure consistency of measurement of the various indicators. These reports would be sent to the CPSU and shared with IDA and IFAD. Where necessary, more detailed studies on specific aspects of project implementation would also be undertaken. 4.21 Impact Evaluation. This would be undertaken by the lead agency, drawing on state level resources as required. The impact assessment exercise would involve: (a) collection of baseline data on a sample of SHG members representative of the different socio-economic and ecological situations in the states, together with collection of data on a control group; (b) development of participatory impact evaluation mechanisms involving the beneficiaries; (c) periodic field surveys to determine the impact of project activities on the beneficiaries' quality of life and their perceptions on the adequacy of project design, and the effectiveness of project implementation; (d) annual review workshops involving beneficiaries; and (e) studies on specific aspects of project impact.

PROJECT IMPACTS AND JUSTIFICATION A. Production and Marketing 5.01 Production. Since the project is not a conventional production oriented project, it is not possible to quantify the aggregate incremental production. However, an indication can be given of the production increases likely to accrue from some of the activities which the women are likely to take up. For typical rainfed crops, per hectare production is expected to increase from 0.48 mt to 0.8 mt for sorghum; from 0.12 mt to 0.3 mt for pulses and from 0.5 mt to 0.9 mt for chillies, whilst for irrigated crops, per hectare production is expected to increase from 1.8 mt to 3.5 mt for paddy and from 0.8 mt to 2.0 mt for wheat. 5.02 Marketing. Agricultural products would be sold principally on local markets. At present, target group households are open to exploitation by traders on whom they depend for credit. With loans available through the SHGs, women would be freed from these tied arrangements. They would also be encouraged to use loans available to delay sale of crops beyond the immediate post-harvest period when prices are depressed, and thus would benefit from the higher prices prevailing at other times. In addition, WDC district staff and NGOs would encourage women to form inter-SHG commodity groups/producers associations which would facilitate group marketing and increase their bargaining power with traders. 5.03 Marketing of the products of non-farm enterprises has posed major problems in the past. Under the project, the situation would be improved through extensive market surveys to identify those products with genuine market potential, and to identify market outlets. Marketing
 -45- consultants will also be engaged to assist the women to establish linkages with the market outlets and negotiate suitable contracts. B. Project Benefits 5.04 Immediate benefits would be seen in: (a) the creation of women's self-help groups and their ability to control income and their own development; (b) enhanced involvement of women in economic activities due to improved access to funds from their own savings and integration into mainstream credit delivery mechanisms; (c) improved management and technical skills; (d) improvements in women's health and reduction of their drudgery; and (f) strengthening of key support agencies enabling them to be more effective in addressing women's needs. Longer term benefits for women would include: (i) increased self-reliance and self- confidence to address their constraints and increased ability to mobilize various public and private sector services for their benefit; and (ii) improvement in their social status in the family and community. It is estimated that the project would assist in the formation of about 7,400 groups benefiting around 130,000 women. C. Economic and Financial Analysis 5.05 Economic Analysis. Given the multi-faceted nature of the project, many of the benefits are not readily quantifiable. The quantifiable benefits relate to project support to increase women's involvement in income generating activities. However, given the flexibility in the credit mechanism and the freedom of choice to be exercised by women in the selection of economic activities, quantification of these benefits involves a high degree of approximation based on assumptions on the proportion of loans given for consumption, social or productive purposes; the rotation of investment funds; and the extent to which project loans replace existing, more expensive sources of credit from the informal sector. Data from the experience of existing SHGs have been used to derive a set of assumptions for the analysis. The analysis assumes: (a) that a range of income generating activities is likely to be taken up by women, with a mix of 85 percent on-farm and 15 percent non-farm activities; (b) the percentage of lending from the group which generates incremental economic benefits would increase from 15 to 40 percent as the group matures; and (c) the rotation of investment funds decreases from 2.0 to 1.5 times per year. All the project costs for direct support to income generating activities have been included in the analysis and it is further assumed that 50 percent of the costs of capacity building of the groups and project implementors, including project management, have a direct impact on the involvement of women in income generating activities. Other assumptions applicable to analysis are: (a) all costs and benefits are in constant June 1996 prices; (b) reference prices for main crops and fertilizers are based on estimated world reference prices adjusted to average project area farm gate values; (c) for other commodities not internationally traded financial prices are adjusted by the Standard Conversion Factor used for India of 0.9;
 -46- (d) project costs and benefits streams are extended over 10 years; (e) opportunity cost of capital is 12%; and (f) project implementation is over five years. On this basis the project yields an economic rate of return of 25 percent and net present value of US$7.8 million. 5.06 Sensitivity analysis. The project is more sensitive to the performance of investment activities taken up than to variations in the overall pattern of lending, as shown by the results of the sensitivity analysis given below: EIRR (i) NPV Rs. million Base case 25 335 Benefits decrease by 10% 12 (10) Activity costs increase by 10% 15 70 Support costs increase by 10% 23 288 Max. 50% of funds generate increm econ benefits 26 367 Max 30% of funds generate increm econ benefits 21 196 1 year lag in investment activities 19 100 5.07 Switching values indicate that project benefits could decrease by 10 percent for the NPV to fall to zero, whilst the costs of the income generating activities could increase by 13 percent and the percentage of funds generating incremental benefits could fall to 20 percent. Further details on the economic analysis are given in Annex 18. 5.08 The other aspects of the project do not lend themselves to quantitative analysis. The principal benefits of the capacity building of groups lie in providing a basis for mutual support which would enable women to manage their own affairs in a more self-reliant manner, and a framework for more cost effective delivery of financial and technical services. The project contributes to building a pool of creditworthy clients for banks and in so doing reduces the risks of the banking system in lending to the rural poor. It is expected that working with groups with a high degree of credit discipline would bring significant economic benefits by increasing recovery rates from around 30-50 percent under individual-based poverty alleviation programs to more than 90 percent through lending to SHGs. The reduction in the default risk also contributes significantly to reducing the overall transaction costs of the banks from around 35 percent when lending to individuals to around 11 percent for lending to SHGs.  -47- 5.09 The investment in capacity building of the WDCs would enable them to be more effective in implementing programs for the economic and social advancement of women. Strengthening the capacity of NGOs would create by the end of the project, a group of NGOs oriented and experienced in the SHG concept and the role that SHGs can play in assisting women's development and empowerment. Capacity building of the other support agencies would make them more aware of women's priorities and more responsive to women's specific needs. The social activities would contribute to improving women's well-being and overall quality of life through improved access to health services and labor saving facilities, thereby reducing drudgery, releasing timne for more productive activities, and increasing productivity. 5.10 The average direct cost per beneficiary is estimated at around US$240 of which US$75 represents direct social intermediation costs (capacity building of groups); US$70 represents technical support for income generating activities and US$95 represents investment funds. The social intermediation costs represent investment in capacity-building at the group level, including credit management and accounting, and developing the groups' sense of ownership which are crucial steps towards sustainability. The remaining project expenditure (around 40 percent of the total) would be on institutional strengthening of the NGOs, WDCs and other project implementors, and on social programs which would provide benefits to a much wider clientele than the immediate project beneficiaries. 5.11 Financial Analysis. Financial models have been prepared for an indicative selection of on-farm and non-farm activities likely to be taken up by women. Increases in incomes from the activities likely to be taken up are variable as these include both supplementary and full-time activities, but they generally exceed Rs. 4,000 per annum, making a substantial contribution to poverty alleviation. These activities yield incremental benefit: cost ratios in excess of 1.5, and provide a return per person-day in excess of Rs. 30 compared with the average wage for women in agricultural labor which is around Rs. 20/day. 5.12 Fiscal Impact. Given the pilot nature of the project, the overall fiscal impact on state and/or central government budgets will be negligible. The expenditures are largely for capacity building of public and private sector agencies and investment in social capital development. In financial terms, the project represents a very small financial burden. No permanent incremental staff would be added to the establishment:of the implementing agencies as they would either be hired on contract or come on deputation from government departments where their posts would be frozen. By the end of the project, SHGs would have developed the capacity to take over many of the responsibilities from NGOs either on a group basis or through the clusters/associationsof SHGs. The CGs/ACs may also be engaged in propagating the SHG concept and assisting the formation of new SHGs, thereby facilitating the expansion of the SHG program at a much reduced cost. While no specific cost recovery measures are proposed in this initial phase of the program, opportunities for partial cost recovery of some social services would be explored during project implementation. Experience from on-going NGO programs suggests that SHG members are willing to pay for services which deliver tangible benefits.
 -48- 5.13 Although the project incorporates an exit strategy for NGO support to SHGs, the phasing of project activities means that around 60 percent of SHGs would still require assistance beyond the project period entailing an expenditure of Rs. 28 million (US$0.8 million) over the subsequent three years. These costs may be reduced to some extent if the process of forming clusters and associations gathers pace and these bodies are able to provide some of the on-going support currently provided by NGOs. D. Social Impact 5.14 Social Assessment. Project interventions are directed towards poor women who have not fully benefited from past interventions in economic or social programs. The project is founded on participatory processes which would enable these women to determine their own strategies for increasing incomes and empowerment. The findings of consultations during project preparation have been incorporated into project planning and design and, together with the concurrent M&E would ensure continued responsiveness of the project to women's expressed needs. More information on the social assessment process is given in Annex 10. 5.15 Indigenous People's Concerns. The proportion of tribal people in most of the 35 districts chosen for the project is low (see Annex 15). However, in some districts, e.g., Panchmahals (Gujarat), Ranchi (Bihar) and Betul (Madhya Pradesh), their proportion is high (above 44 percent) thus making tribal women major potential beneficiaries of the project. The group members would decide the nature as well as operational modalities of group activities, and the project's approach would ensure the appropriateness of investments for tribal communities. Its interventions for savings and credit, skills training and market linkages are even more germane to tribal women on account of the poverty and poor resource base of tribal areas. The intermediation of NGOs with mainstream institutions, such as financial institutions and line departments, to ensure the provision of improved services would address some of the major constraints faced by tribal people. Further, the approach of the project to entrust decision making powers to SHGs and provide members with functional literacy, and communities with assets, basic health care and child care, would fill major gaps that persist in the social services in tribal areas. More information on the needs of tribal women is given in Annex 15. At Negotiations, the government provided assurances that where the project is implemented in any state tribal area, each project state, in consultation with SHG members, would develop implementation arrangements covering project's activities satisfactory to the Association. E. Environmental Impact 5.16 The proposed project would be unlikely to have any negative impact on the environment. In the course of the participatory processes for selection of income generating activities, Animal Husbandry staff would assist SHG members who are considering taking loans for livestock to consider the crucial issue of fodder availability in the local area. Micro-enterprise activities would be small artisan-based enterprises which will neither adversely affect the natural resource base nor cause atmospheric pollution.
 -49- F. Sustainability 5.17 A major thrust of the project is capacity building of SHGs so that they are capable of managing their own affairs, and are able to further their own social and economic development by virtue of the awareness created and linkages established with lending institutions and technical support agencies. The expected high repayment rates and reduction in transaction costs for the banks should ensure a continuing flow of credit to the groups. The project design allocates substantial responsibilities and resources to non-governmental entities, with 36 percent of total project costs flowing to SHGs and 47 percent to NGOs and other contracted specialists, while project expenditures flowing to government to improve capacity amount to only 17 percent. Building the capacity of mature SHGs to promote the formation of additional SHGs contribute to a more cost-effective and sustainable approach to the formation of SHGs. Through this approach, the direct NGO support costs are estimated to reduce by around 50 percent. In addition, the formation of clusters of SHGs and cluster associations would over time, be expected to take over many of the support functions provided by NGOs, whilst also playing a vital role in the wider replication of the SHG concept. G. Risks 5.18 The proposed project carries several risks. Some are general problems associated with implementation of projects in India including late start-up, frequent management turnover, and weak implementation capacity. Most of these risks have been substantially reduced through project design which places a strong emphasis on organizational capacity building, recruitment of project management staff at senior levels on a longterm contractual basis to counter the high turnover of government officers, recruitment of key staff as a condition of Negotiations to facilitate project start-up, and launching of pre-project activities including hiring of NGOs, formation of SHGs, and orientation of project implementors, to expedite project implementation and generate experience. 5.19 There are other risks specifically associated with the project. First, an adequate number of competent NGOs may not be found to form and support SHGs, which may also result in overloading the limited number of experienced NGOs. To address this, the project would support capacity building of motivated NGOs which presently lack experience of SHG formation, which would allow many small NGOs to participate. In addition, transparent contractual arrangements with appropriate funding, specifying roles and responsibilities of public institutions, NGOs and SHGs have been developed to provide for a supportive environment for project implementation. 5.20 Second, the WDCs may not develop adequate capacity to coordinate the project activities effectively. Institutional strengthening of the WDCs through staffing with relevant expertise accompanied by orientation and training of staff would be emphasized in the project to address this risk. Phased implementation of the project would ensure that adequate training is provided before coverage is expanded to new districts. Feedback from the concurrent M&E system would indicate the readiness of the WDCs to cope with an expanded area of operation. 5.21 Third, insufficient support may be provided by the technical line departnents to back-up income generating activities and provide social services. The project addresses this risk
 -50- through a strong emphasis on building the capacity of support agencies, including gender sensitization to encourage line departments to be more responsive to women's needs. In addition, the participatory nature of the project and the emphasis on empowering women would make the public services more accountable to the SHG members. Funds are available under the project to strengthen linkages with line departments and to tap other sources of technical support where deficiencies are experienced. An associated risk is the limited capacity within some states to support micro-enterprises. To address this, the project would finance support from successful private sector women entrepreneurs to help in identification and capacity building of local entrepreneurs who are willing to assist SHG members to establish new enterprises of their own choice and/or develop market linkages for businesses. 5.22 A fourth risk is that banks may not be as responsive as envisaged in providing loans to the groups. The project seeks to reduce this risk through investing in strengthening of linkages between lending institutions, NGOs and SHGs and in capacity building of the groups to establish a track record of sound credit management to make them attractive clients for the banks. 5.23 A final risk is that the women may be constrained in generating additional income due to difficulties in overcoming time and labor constraints. To address this, the project provides support for activities to reduce drudgery and improve access to social services, especially health and child care facilities. VI.  -65- Annex 2 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT LESSONS LEARNED FROM TAMIL NADU WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT PROJECT A. Project Background 1. The Tamil Nadu Women's Development Project commenced its implementation in 1989. The overall responsibility for project implementation lies with MAHAM (Tamil Nadu Women's Development Corporation), which is a wholly owned Government of Tamil Nadu undertaking. The principal objective of the project is the economic and social upliftment of women to enhance the welfare of their families and to improve their status in the family and the community. The objective of social advancement would be achieved through raising women's level of awareness and fostering the confidence to strive for social change through the development of strong, cohesive groups as a source of mutual support of the women and the provision of an animator within the village to motivate and guide them. Improvement in their economic position would be achieved through increasing their income eaming potential by integrating them into the regular delivery system for credit and technical support services. In order to overcome inadequacies in the selection of beneficiaries under existing government programs, the project would involve NGOs in the initial screening process. The entry point and central feature of the project was to be the fornation of savings and credit groups to meet women's needs for crisis credit. 2. The major innovative features introduced into the project approach included the use of animators working at the village level to mobilize women; greater participation of women in decision making; greater emphasis on promoting self-reliance through self-managed group savings funds and group credit; improvement in the selection of suitable economic activities and assistance to formal credit development. 3. The project introduced three specific features to underpin the credit system. First, it focused on developing the savings and loan activities of the groups to provide the small amounts of credit for emergency, social or production purposes, which would not be available from the banks and for which women would otherwise have recourse to money-lenders. Secondly, it involved the participating banks in the vetting and selection of beneficiaries from the outset thus building the confidence of the formal credit agencies in the system. Thirdly, it used the animators and the groups themselves in deciding on the suitability of both beneficiaries and activities thereby utilizing local knowledge of applicants and inculcating a sense of responsibility for credit within the women's own organizations.
 -66- Annex 2 4. A Mid-Term Evaluation of the project was carried out in January-February 1995 providing valuable provisional information on the impact of the project and on the lessons to be learned from project implementation. These provide guidance for the design of the present project. B. Project Impact 5. The project has shown considerable achievements. It has almost reached its quantitative targets of loans disbursed and has overachieved by 40 percent the number of groups to be formed. Qualitatively, there is evidence of considerable social impact of the project on women, particularly in well functioning, homogenous groups of very poor women where women report a greater degree of self-confidence, greater mobility and greater ease to visit banks and converse with different officials. Landless women report a significant social change where they were formerly laborers and are now small scale entrepreneurs as a result of obtaining loans under the project. For other women, the most important social impact has been their ability to get out of the house and attend group meetings, particularly where considerable opposition from their husbands in the beginning had to be overcome. 6. Group membership has allowed women to undertake many collective actions ranging from petitions for street lighting to arranging for milk routes to stop in their village. The social impact appears to have been greater in empowering women in the public rather than in the private sphere. Women have reported feeling bolder now to go to agencies for inputs, to visit banks and to talk with officials visiting the village. The project seems to have enabled women to develop appropriate attitudes as well as skills and know how in dealing with external "modern" institutions (NGOs, line agencies, banks, etc.). 7. One of the positive features has been the kind of coordination achieved among NGOs, banks, and line departments due to the proactive role played by the MAHAM and the Project Implementation Units (PIUs). In addition, the bank has seen in the project a good opportunity for developing poor rural clients and graduating them to regular bank borrowers. 8. The strongest positive points of the project are: (a) women's groups have been formed and the group members have been helped to develop the habit of systemic savings; (b) the project has made it possible for unregistered self-help women's groups to open savings bank accounts, an important achievement in itself; (c) in groups where women had the chance to take and repay several, small, internal loans for a variety of purposes, they have been able to develop a "repayment culture"; (d) the recovery rate of the bank loans is excellent due to the extensive support system developed by the project. The project has demonstrated that banks can give loans to women's self-help groups and to enjoy high repayment rates. This is important in the current climate of market orientation and liberalization in which banking institutions are likely to shy away from providing credit to the poor, especially poor women, because of the high transaction costs involved and the perceived risk factor involved in repayments; and (e) the cooperation
 -67- Annex 2 between the Government, the Women's Development Corporation (WDC) and officers from the line departments, the bank and the NGOs achieved in this project represents an important model to be emulated. C. Lessons Learned Role of Intervenors 9. Non-governmental Organizations (NGOs). The Tamil Nadu Mid-Term Evaluation Report (MTER) highlights the key role that NGOs have played in the implementation of the project; the quality of the group was mainly dependent on the type of orientation provided by the NGO. It however stresses that even well qualified NGOs need to be monitored especially with regard to the progress and quality of groups and the relevance and adequacy of training provided. To shift the focus on "quality", the report suggests that NGOs should be paid not exclusively on the basis of beneficiaries receiving loans as is the present practice, but also on the number of groups trained in group dynamics and technical skills. 10. The MTER draws attention to the variation in group quality and performance due to the difference among NGOs in terms of philosophy, management style and experience with credit programs. It also highlights the need to take a cautious approach to building on existing groups which have been formed for a different purpose and to evaluate carefully how effectively they can be modified to fit in with the project's objectives. When existing groups were transformed into IFAD groups the members (and often the focus) did not change; as a result several well to do women remained as members of the IFAD group, other groups were too large to function as effective SHGs, yet others were formed into clusters without first consolidating the SHGs at the base leading to top-down systems of management. I1. District Project Implementation Unit. It was originally envisaged that the Project Coordinator would not only be a senior person but also one with experience in participatory management, interaction with other institutions, especially with NGOs, and who is committed to the project, open to new ideas and has confidence in other people's institutions as part of a sustainable strategy. This has not been implemented. In addition, brief postings of one year of officials from the main line departments, especially of those who are not happy with the transfer, undermine the project. 12. The MTER also stresses the need for a Project Implementation Unit (PIU) at district level arguing that a Coordination Committee of district heads of technical departments supported by a nodal officer cannot perform the same functions as a PIU. However, it is not necessary for the PIU to have a large contingent of technical staff on deputation from each line department. 13. Technical Support. The MTER draws particular attention to the lack of support provided by the line departments, particularly in the field of animal husbandry. This has had a
 -68- Annex 2 serious impact on a large number of people since over 45 percent of the loanees have opted for milk animals. The report points out that several of these animals were not of good quality - one of the reasons being that the market price of a productive animal was below the approved unit cost (INR 10 000 versus INR 14 000); but it also highlights other reasons for which the veterinary department involved needs to share responsibility, for example: inadequate provision of fodder; high costs of purchasing fodder and concentrates; lack of professional advice and training in management relating to health, feed needs and breeding; inadequate veterinary services, usually difficult to access; the difficulty to maintain monthly repayments especially when milk yield falls. 14. Animators. The MTER highlights the crucial role that animators play; they have had a strong impact on the groups. The tendency to dominate the group, however, was clearly noticeable. The MTER emphasizes the need for training animators in participatory skills so that they are equipped to support the emergence of other leaders within the group who in turn will be mutually supportive. The report points out the need for the animators honorarium to be met by the group and indicates from its study of several groups that this is feasible from the fifth year onwards. The report indicates that animators in some areas tend to include women in the group with whom they can relate resulting in a group where the literacy rate as well as the economic status of members is relatively high. 15. Banks. Only one commercial bank is involved in financing under the Tamil Nadu project. As a result in certain areas, the presence of banks is inadequate in relation to the number of groups resulting in an over-load on one branch and considerable inconvenience and cost to the borrowers. It concludes that a branch finds it difficult to handle more than 50 groups without computerizing its operations which it is estimated would cost INR 0.2 million per branch. The MTER also highlights the elaborate procedures required for loan disbursement. 16. The MTER recommends that the National Project should give consideration to adopting the group lending approach using the pattern proposed under the Reserve Bank of India circular and National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development guidelines allowing banks to finance SHGs directly as bankable institutions - no records of individual member loans need be maintained by the bank. Group Formation and Management 17. The MTER states that "an important lesson learned from the Tamil Nadu project is that one of the best indicators of the dynamism and cohesion of a group is the degree of rotation to all members of small, internal loans based on their savings prior to applying for bank loans. Groups which were not constrained from doing this due to local bank rules obliging them to keep their savings as bank deposits and were able to postpone the application for bank loans for at least a year, were able to develop a sense of self-reliance and solidarity as well as a repayment culture. It would, therefore, be very important to ensure that in the National Project, NGO and bank regulations are favorable in allowing groups to experience a high degree of small,
 -69- Annex 2 internal loans for a minimum of a year". The report suggests that no bank loans are to be given until the groups have acquired the habit of regular savings credited to a common fund and experience of revolving these savings through internal loans. It suggests that groups must have the experience of saving and lending for at least one year before loans are provided. The practice adopted by banks of holding the savings as a kind of collateral or risk coverage therefore must be discontinued. 18. The report also stresses the need for improvement in the quality of record keeping. Most of the NGOs were not well equipped to maintain book of accounts and to audit the common fund of the groups. They need to be provided with technical support to improve their performance. 19. Factors Enhancing Group Sustainability. The Review Mission found that the following factors enhanced group solidarity and group sustainability: size - small groups less than 25; homogeneity - similar socio-economic background; degree of rotation of the common fund based on savings before project loans were availed of; training of animators in group dynamics and management; quantum and rate of savings - high rate generated confidence in their own efforts; broad spectrum of group activities to include provision of service which also increased the common fund and supported group action. 20. Federations. Attempts to create some kind of group federation should not be undertaken until the groups have attained a mature level of functioning, appreciate the importance of such federation, and are in a position to control it. The present experience indicates that such federations should be limited to a social and information sharing role, and refrain from playing any kind of financial role. 21. Target Group. The MTER noted that even with well defined target group criteria of poor women, the most disadvantaged women, namely the landless, women from marginal farm families and female headed households, have not been adequately represented in the groups. This has arisen partly from the tendency of the animator to select women with whom she felt comfortable and to whom she could relate as they were literate. It has also arisen through a misconception of the need to give emphasis to land based activities. Training 22. The MTER stresses that the content and quality of training differs from NGO to NGO. It is much below the standard required in many cases and the NGOs need to be trained particularly in: group dynamics; group management; gender and poverty issues; credit related issues; and participatory planning skills. This service could be provided by larger experienced NGOs and/or consultants.

 -75- Annex 3 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT STATUS OF WOMEN, TARGET GROUP AND PROJECT AREA A. STATUS OF WOMEN 1. Women in India have come a long way in the last quarter of a century. Improved household food security, an expanding health care system, and maternal and child health interventions have brought about impressive gains in women's health status. The life expectancy for females at birth has risen from about 32 years in 1951 to about 60 years in 1991. The death rate of females has declined significantly, and in 1991 was marginally lower for females than for males (9.8 vs. 10.1). The infant mortality (IMR) differential between females and males has also been bridged, with a male IMR of 81 and a female IMR of 80 per 1,000 live births. The maternal mortality rate is about 40 per 10,000 live births. The girl child has become the focus of the universal primary education campaign, and in 1993-94, 71.4 percent of the girls of primary school age were enrolled in primary school. 2. Yet women in India remain one of the most disadvantaged groups in society. Viewed against almost all indicators of development, women continue to lag behind men. There are only 927 women for every 1,000 men in India. Women's access to literacy and education is more limited. Only 39.4 percent of women are literate against 63.8 percent for men. Of the 324 million illiterates enumerated in the 1991 Census, 61 percent were women and girls. School enrolment exhibits similar gender disparities particularly at secondary and higher levels of education. The employment record of women shows more women in the unorganised sector and in unskilled and lesser paid jobs. Malnutrition is significantly higher amongst girls than boys, whilst even as adults, women frequently do not have equal access to food within the farnily. Despite women's higher morbidity, far fewer women than men use health services. 3. The continued disadvantaged of women in large measure stems from entrenched social attitudes. Whilst the Constitution guaranteed formal equality and radical social legislation enacted in recent decades has introduced important innovations in the Indian social structure affecting women's status and role, the enactment of laws does not change attitudes and the views of society towards the position of women have changed little over the years. Devaluation of women commences at birth with the preference for male offspring and continues through a childhood of conditioning to the submissive, subservient role required of them in the marital home. A woman is never viewed as a person in her own right but always as someone's daughter, wife or mother. Within the family, a woman is a social dependent, her worth measured in terms of her ability to produce male children. Widows represent a particularly vulnerable group of women, largely debarred from remarriage and socially ostracised. Although forming a minority of women, in absolute numbers widows represent a large group of women subjected to a great deal of suffering.
 -76- Annex 3 Where young brides have been married to older men, many widows can be quite young with young children to support. The plight of many widows is hidden where they remain part of their husband's family but are frequently neglected and ill-treated. 4. The position of women in the social structure affects the way they are regarded in their economic roles. Although women are major contributors to the survival of the family and are vital and productive workers in India's national economy, this is largely unrecognised. The poorer the family, the greater its dependence on women's economic productivity. Women contribute a much larger share of their earnings to basic family maintenance than do men. Studies in Kerala and Tamil Nadu found that despite women's lower wage rates and fewer days of paid employment, (which meant that women's incomes were between one-third and one-half of their husband's income), women's contribution to the household budget was greater. Whilst on average women's earnings represented 53 percent of the earnings of their husbands, women's contribution to household maintenance averaged 72 percent. Women on average contributed 98 percent of their earnings towards family maintenance whilst men contributed only 78 percent. There is clear evidence that women's income contributes markedly to family welfare through better health and nutrition, particularly of children. In spite of this, women lack access to the resources which could increase their productivity and earning potential. Social attitudes, which always view women as only supplementary income earners even when they contribute 50-100 percent of the family income, restrict them to low paid, unskilled occupations. More than 90 percent of rural women workers are unskilled. Around 90 percent of women are engaged in the informal unorganised sector and of these around 80 percent are in agriculture. Wage rates in agriculture are on average 30 to 50 percent less than for men. Female casual laborers in rural India show the highest incidence of poverty of any occupational category, male or female. Women have little access to land and other productive assets and this lack of collateral largely excludes them from institutional credit and forces them to depend on high cost informal sources of credit to secure capital for self-employment activities. Women also generally lack the bureaucratic know-how to make the system work for them. 5. Rural women living below the poverty line are mostly engaged in agriculture and animal husbandry. Landless women engage in non-farm activities during the lean agriculture periods, but the major part of their earnings come from agricultural labor. Women are responsible for 70 to 80 percent of field work, whilst most post harvest and processing tasks are solely their responsibility. However, stark gender divisions assign all activities involving direct manual labor to women whilst all operations involving draught animals or machinery are generally performed by men. Women are also heavily involved in animal husbandry, particularly small livestock, whilst women account for 85 percent of the labor engaged in dairy production. 6. In addition to their contribution to household income, women shoulder the entire burden of household activities and child care responsibilities. Poor women generally work longer hours than their menfolk - up to 14-16 hours per day. At the aggregate level 58 percent of women's work time is spent in conventional activities such as cooking, cleaning and child care.
 -77- Annex 3 7. There is a strong correlation between a woman's access to independent income and her control over the family's resources. The ability to earn and control income is one of the most powerful determinants of a woman's status in the family. Strategies for women's empowerment therefore need to take note of the need to increase women's income. The Bank's research' indicates that expanding women's economic opportunities and increasing the income they control results in greater economic efficiency, improved child health and nutrition and reduced poverty. 8. A disproportionate burden of poverty is suffered by female-headed households (FHHs) which are noted to be much more poverty prone than male-headed households. Female heads are usually widowed, separated or divorced, with much less access to and control over land, greater dependency on wage labor for employment, a higher incidence of voluntary unemployment, and lower levels of education and literacy. Female heads of households form a higher percentage of the lower income deciles - often being amongst the poorest of the poor. At the same time, the delivery structures of credit, technical advice, etc., do not reach them as institutions are slow to recognise women as heads of households. The smaller size of FHHs also implies a lower availability of household labor which affects their ability to undertake economic activities. 9. The position of women varies across regions and according to the economic status of the household and its place in the caste hierarchy. On the whole, the position of women is more constrained in the north (covering Haryana, Bihar, and Uttar Pradesh amongst the project states) than in the south (including Karnataka). Female labor force participation rates are lower, and female land ownership is far less common in the north Health indicators, such as female infant mortality, and overall sex ratios, are more heavily biased against females in the north. Female literacy is lower in the north than in the south, whilst purdah, high dowry payments and violence against women are all much more prevalent in the north. Regional differences are further modified by caste and economic circumstances. Constraints on women are stronger among caste Hindus than amongst Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST) - and stronger amongst land-owning cultivators than among landless laborers or marginal farm families. Among the poor who cannot afford female seclusion, women have always entered the labor force when they could find work.  -78- Annex 3 B. Target Group 10. Definition of the Target Group. The target group for the project would be women below the poverty line in rural areas as defined by the Government of India (GOI) normn, viz., INR I 1 000 per household of 5.5 persons. Particular emphasis would be given to including both dejure and the more numerous defacto female-headed households who constitute the most disadvantaged groups of women (for the country as a whole, 30 percent of households are estimated to be female headed). The project would also seek to include widows and deserted women who, although re- integrated into extended farnilies, frequently live abject lives as a result of their lack of independent means. Particular attention would also be given to ensuring that the most marginal women, particularly the landless, are included. In order to ensure strong, cohesive and sustainable affinity groups, no eligibility criteria would be set beyond the poverty criterion in order to allow women genuine freedom of choice in group membership. 11. Procedures for Identification of the Target Group. Beneficiary targeting would be the responsibility of the NGOs. While the list of below poverty families (BPL) would be used as a starting point, the NGOs would have the flexibility to assess the validity of potential beneficiaries and, in particular, to include women who are not on the BPL list but are clearly adjudged to be below the poverty line. The targeting process would follow a number of sequential steps. First, keeping in mind the cluster approach, groups of villages with a high percentage of poor households would be selected. Within the villages/hamlets, potential beneficiary groups would be identified through regular visits to the village, informal talks when people gather, and participatory processes involving the whole community in identifying the social spectrum of the village, and the community's perceptions of who is poor. The NGO would then interact with the identified potential beneficiaries to promote the idea of the formation of an affinity group to seek to solve their problems of poverty and discrimination. Out of this exercise would emerge self-selected groupings of poor women motivated to work together for their self-enhancement. 12. Profile of the Target Group. The target group would largely comprise women from marginal and small farm households and landless families. The landless and near landless are estimated to represent around 30 percent of rural households. While around 30 percent of households in the country as a whole are estimated to be female headed, in some of the more socially conservative states such as Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, the percentage is likely to be lower due to social practices of absorbing widows into the husband's extended family. 13. The percentage of marginal farm families in the project districts ranges from 18 to 76 percent. The majority of women are engaged in agriculture, with the percentage of the female workforce involved in agriculture ranging from 75 percent in Karnataka to 90 percent in Bihar. The percentage of the female workforce engaged as agricultural laborers ranges from 35 percent in Uttar Pradesh to 59 percent in Bihar.
 -79- Annex 3 14. The target group would comprise a high proportion of SC and ST. Overall the presence of SC in the project districts ranges from 4 percent (Panchmahals, Gujarat) to 32 percent (Hardoi, UP). The largest concentrations of ST population in the project area are found in Bihar (43% in Ranchi) and in Gujarat (47% in Panchmahals and 46% in Baruch). 15. The position of women and the level of deprivation differs from state to state and class to class. Within a region, differences exist between rural and urban women with rural poor women generally being the most disadvantaged. Although there exists a broad correlation between status of women and the general economic backwardness of the state, there are exceptions such as in Haryana where the status of women continues to be much lower despite the high rate of economic growth that the state has achieved. 16. In addition to regional differences, there are also significant differences on caste and class lines within the regions. Constraints on women appear to be stronger among caste Hindus than among the SC and ST, and stronger among land-owning cultivators than among landless laborers or marginal farm families. Thus the fact that SC/ST, the landless and marginal farm families will predominate in the target group means that the degree of social oppression faced by the target group is likely to be somewhat diminished. In addition, the poor are known to be more open and receptive to change, having less at stake than the privileged and hence, within the family, the scope for change would seem to be more propitious. However, by virtue of society's views with regard to poverty, gaining recognition within the community may prove more difficult. Paradoxically, the experience of the Tamil Nadu project has been that women have made more advancement in public life than in their private lives. C. Project Area 17. The project area comprises the six states of Bihar, Gujarat, Haryana, Kamataka, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. Within each state the project would be implemented in a limited number of districts. The criteria for the selection of districts are as follows: (a) high incidence of poverty as reflected in the percentage of population below the poverty line; (b) high incidence of disadvantaged groups as reflected in the percentage of Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe population in the district; (c) ad-7erse status of women as reflected in adverse sex ratio and female illiteracy; (d) representation of regional socio-economic variations within the state to ensure testing of project interventions under all circumstances during the initial phase of project implementation; and (e) implementation capacity as reflected in the availability of suitable NGOs, lending institutions and other public and private sector agencies providing support services.
 -80- Annex 3 18. Project activities would start in one or two districts in each state. A limited number of additional districts would be brought under the project in a phased manner in accordance with the increasing experience and implementation capacity. Uttar Pradesh is an exception as the project would be building on the experience gained in the formation of women's SHGs by the UP Land Development Corporation under the World Bank-assisted Sodic Lands Reclamation Project which operates in 13 districts. In addition, two new districts (Sitapur and Bandha) would be taken up within UP where the work could be coordinated by the UP Women's Welfare Corporation. Feedback from the M&E system would indicate the readiness of states to expand the program into new districts. The situation would be reviewed and any necessary changes made at the Mid-Term Review.
