 -87- Annex 4 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT SELF-HELP GROUP CONCEPT A. Role of Groups 1. Group formation is seen as crucial to the empowerment process as women draw strength from numbers. The group provides: (a) confidence and mutual support for women striving for social change; (b) a forum in which women can critically analyze their situations and devise collective strategies to overcome their difficulties; (c) a framework for awareness raising, confidence building, dissemination of inforrnation and delivery of services, and for developing communal self-reliance and collective action; and (d) a vehicle for the promotion of economic activities. B. SHG Concept 2. The project has adopted the self-help group (SHG) as the appropriate people's institution which provides poor women with the space and support necessary to take effective steps towards greater control of their lives in private and in society. The essence of an SHG is that it lays the foundation for self-reliance through building up an institution which has the capacity to continue the development and empowerment processes for women in the future. Self-help promotion attempts to raise the choice level of the poor by building up an institutional framework that is in tune with their capacities of self administration and better geared towards serving their needs. Until now this potential of the rural poor of helping themselves has been underestimated and therefore underexplored. Efforts were not made to stimulate the capacity of the rural poor to help themselves. 3. Savings and credit is put forward as an important entry point for the activities of SHGs as requires the active participation and commitment of all members. It provides them with an opportunity to exercise control and participate in decision making. It also satisfies a short term needs for crisis credit (for consumption and emergency purposes), leading later to the provision of credit for productive purposes, and removes them from exploitation at the hands of the money- lenders. The self-help group is seen as a dynamic institution, which builds on the resources and management skills of its members and their increasing confidence to become involved in issues and programs. C. Essential Features of SHGs 4. As the concept of SHGs and the strategy to form such groups is not widely known or practised in most of the project areas, detailed information is provided on the essential features of SHGs, their characteristics, benefits and contribution to the overall empowerment and development objectives of the project. In addition, a detailed description is provided on the SHG formation and development process. This is followed by a discussion on the role of the NGOs as intervenors and ways in which other agencies can be used to supplement the available NGOs in the process of forming SHGs.
 -88- Annex 4 5. Some of the essential features of SHGs are: (a) Ownership of the group by the members. The group exists because the members see some value in it in helping them to solve their problems through their collective efforts. Ownership and control of the group belongs to the members and not to the promoting institution, be it an NGO or government. (b) Affinity as the base for coming together. A sustainable, cohesive group needs a common underlying bond on which trust can be built. This may be caste, sub-caste, blood, community, place of origin, occupation, etc. The intervenors (whether from the NGO, bank or government) must have the experience to be able to identify these natural groupings or affinity groups. It is, therefore, essential that the groups are formned naturally and by the will of the women themselves. (c) Mutual help as the foundation of the group's existence. The rationale for the existence of the group is mutual help and progress towards self-reliance and not the passive receipt of benefits. (d) Forumfor collective learning. The groups provide a forum for collective learning which rural people find more "friendly", based on mutual respect/support, and which is consequently more effective than the individual approach that is commonly adopted. (e) Forum for inter-agency dialogue and cooperation. The groups provide a firn base for dialogue and cooperation in programs with other institutions like government departments, cooperatives, financial and panchayat institutions; if the groups are functioning well, they have the credibility and the power to ensure their participation in identifying, planning, budgeting and implementation of programs for the empowerment of women with a special focus on the poor. (f) Cost-effective credit delivery mechanism. The group provides a cost effective credit delivery system as the transactions costs of lending decrease sharply both to the banks and the borrowers. At the same time, individual members maintain control over the pace, timing, size and schedules of loans and programs. The group also helps to build the individual member's management capacity to optimize returns. D. Indicative SHG Development Process Operations of SHGs 6. Group size should be kept small, less than 20 members in order to ensure the necessary trust and confidence essential for building a cohesive group. Groups of this size are also a prerequisite to be treated as informal entities for the purposes of linkage with the banks'. Prima facie, SHGs with more than 20 members would attract the provisions of the Companies Act, 1956 which requires all associations of more than 20 persons formed for the purposes of acquisition of gain by the association or its individual members to be registered as a company under this Act.
 -89- Annex 4 7. It is essential that the groups are democratically managed and all decisions concerning the group are made on the basis of group consensus. All SHG members would participate in the decision making processes and no executive committee would be formed as suspicion may crop up when the ownership and management of the SHG diverge which could prove fatal to the existence of the SHG. 8. Each group would, with the assistance of the NGO, frame its own regulations for the operation of the group savings or common fund, on the basis of group consensus, covering minimum amount of monthly or weekly savings; maximum loan amount for the first and subsequent loans; interest rates; repayment periods; penalties and action to be taken in the event of default; eligibility criteria for loans; allocation of loans between consumption and production, etc. 9. Regular meetings are important for cementing groups. Ideally groups should meet weekly but the minimum would be monthly. At least one formal business meeting, at which all members would be expected to attend, should be conducted each month. All the operations of the savings and loans fund would be conducted at this meeting. Members would be required to bring their savings and loan repayments to these meetings, applications for loans would be discussed by all the group members and loans would be sanctioned and disbursed during the meeting (depending on the availability of funds). The NGO field worker would initially attend these meetings to provide advice if required and to check that the accounts are maintained correctly. If the group meets weekly or fortnightly, savings and loans business can be transacted more frequently. However, the other meetings should be used primarily for discussions linked to awareness raising; follow-up informal interactive training sessions on group dynamics, leadership, etc., by the NGO field worker or training on special topics, e.g., health, nutrition, agriculture, etc., at which outside resource persons would be invited to attend. In addition, one meeting a month should be devoted to compiling the letter for exchanging with other groups. 10. Since most of the transactions would take place on this one day each month, liquidity management should not prove to be much of a problem for the group as it is expected that the majority of the savings would be loaned directly so that the problem of sizable surpluses would not arise. A portion of any surplus funds would be kept in the cash box to be immediately available to meet emergency needs of members. Most groups agree that the two representatives may decide on emergency loans to group members up to a set amount to be formally sanctioned at the next group meeting. The cash box would have two locks with one key held by each of the group representatives. Additional surpluses would be deposited in the bank. Similarly for loans sanctioned in excess of the cash collected at the meeting, additional cash would be drawn from the bank and disbursed to the borrowers at the next meeting. 11. The representatives would prepare a report and financial statement to the group every six months. These half-yearly meetings would also be used for amending regulations and policies. As the capital accumulations of the group increase over the years, the opportunity for the greater use of loans for productive purposes would grow and groups would be guided towards granting larger loans with longer repayment periods. Groups would generally recognize the need to charge lower interest rates on longer term loans.
 -90- Annex 4 12. Loans would initially be provided mainly for consumption purposes but as the savings fund grows and the group gains experience in managing the fund, more loans would be given for small productive purposes. This would enable the group to gain experience of managing credit, learn credit discipline and build up a track record of sound credit management making it an attractive client for the bank. 13. Experience shows that women's needs and ability to manage credit through their groups rapidly outgrows the limitations of their own resources. Hence, after a minimum of six months and more usually nine months, and based on the performance of the group in managing the funds, the banks would be encouraged to provide a bulk loan to the group to be disbursed by the group to its members as individual loans for both consumption and productive purposes - the group would be responsible for repayment to the bank. Initially this linkage with the bank would take the form of a line of credit (cash credit limit), initially equivalent to the group's savings (see Annex 7, para 12 for further details). The cash credit limit is gradually raised in line with the bank's increasing confidence in the group's credit management record. Over time, the group may, in consultation with the bank, decide to progress to a group term loan or it may prefer to continue with the cash credit arrangements. This process would constitute the beginning of a sustainable relationship with the bank providing for a continual flow of credit to the group beyond the project period. 14. At the same time, the SHGs would provide the platform for other aspects of empowerment such as literacy, dissemination of information on family welfare, health and nutrition, financial management, legal rights, etc., and the base for social action. Participatory processes involving the husbands' participation would be encouraged on occasions to discuss relationships within the family, participation in decision making and control of income and sharing of non-economic family responsibilities in order to begin to break down stereotyped roles and to foster "togetherness" in male/female relationships and a working towards the goal of a more equal partnership in the family. 15. Once groups have became mature (after 3-4 years) the concept of individual savings accounts with the group from which women would be able to withdraw their savings could be introduced, initially on a pilot basis. This would permit women with a greater capacity to save to have access to their savings while increasing the loanable funds of the group (see Annex 7, para 11). Group Development Process 16. Based on the present accumulated experience, the process of SHG formation and development can be separated into three phases as indicated below. This also emphasizes the part to be played by the NGO field worker at each stage and the features of the SHG at the end of each phase. Groups would develop at their own pace and hence the timings given are purely indicative and will vary from group to group. Phase I - Identification and Formation of SHGs: 0 - 4 months 17. This is a critical function on which depends all the further progress of the group. The NGO as intervenor plays a key role here in identifying affinity groups to form the basis of the SHG. This is where the experience of the NGO is crucial.
 -91- Annex 4 18. The means used by the intervenors to identify these affinity groups are several; a few popular ones are: regular visits to the village, meeting with informal groups gathered around tea shops, temples, water spots, markets, provision shops, milk collection centers; special care should be given to visit and interact in areas where the scheduled castes and tribes live and where women tend to gather; involvement in a common action like desilting a pond, or building a road also helps to identify these groups, provided people organize the action themselves; it is noticed that in such cases they tend to work in affinity groups; participatory appraisal methods are useful since they too involve all the community in various exercises which help to identify the various groupings in the village, the assets and resources of each family, people's perception of who is poor, their credit needs, incomes and seasonal variations; the community is involved in collecting and correcting data in a manner in which all can participate using instruments to which they are accustomed such as sticks, stones, seeds, colored powders, etc. during the participatory process background information which will be useful in subsequent stages of the group's activities, e.g., when it begins to focus on economic activities, is also collected viz., the availability of natural resources, activities undertaken, skills, markets, perceptions on poverty and de, elopment constraints, etc. These topics would be addressed later in a more expanded fashion at the appropriate time. 19. During this phase, since the SHGs are entirely composed of women, it has been found necessary to meet with men and to explain what is going on and especially the benefits that will accrue to the family through SHGs. Group formation is not complete with the first meeting. It takes several meetings over a period of 2 to 4 months for the group to establish a definite membership. During this period members may leave and others may join if the group agrees. 20. The meetings held during this period are not only social gatherings; the members also raise issues concerning the family and the village. Matters regarding savings and lending are also debated thoroughly as this is the major common function of the group. Agreement to save and to lend indicates a degree of trust in one another, the willingness to abide by group decisions without breaking bonds and confidence in the group; these are the building blocks of effective SHGs. 21. In this initial phase it is necessary that intervenors have experience in identifying and forming SHGs and care should be taken to ensure that the NGOs place experienced staff, at least at middle management level, to play a key role during this phase. 22. Critical Features of the SHG at the End of Phase I. These include: - the membership of the group is identifiable and stable.
 -92- Annex 4 the group has given itself a name. two members of the group have been elected/selected as the group's representatives. the date, time and place of meetings has been decided on by the members and meetings are held regularly according to the schedule the members have agreed to save regularly, to create a habit of thrift and to establish a culture of self help. Some groups may have started savings. If savings have begun, the group has opened an account in the nearest bank or Post Office. The account has two signatories, either one from the SHG and the other from the NGO intervenor or both from the SHG. basic records like (i) attendance register; (ii) minutes book; and (iii) members savings ledgers and individual savings pass books (if savings have started) are being maintained. Phase II - Group Stabilization: 4 months to 15 months 23. The key activities which take place during this important phase in the development of the SHG are: Savings are regular and lending operations gather strength. This provides the members of the SHG with an opportunity to acquire the skills to manage its resources. The group decides on the rate of savings, on the timing of the loans, on the schedule of payments and repayments; it assess whether the member is able to manage the asset for which she has asked for a loan and decides on priorities. Meetings are held regularly; preferably every week; attendance is maintained and averages over 80 percent; repayments average over 90 percent; sanctions for default on repayment and for deviant behavior (smoking, arriving late for meetings, etc.) are imposed and accepted. The minutes and accounts books are maintained either by a member or by the NGO staff or preferably by someone from the village who is paid by the SHG for such services. Gender issues concerning women in private and public life are raised and discussed. Literacy and numeracy classes are conducted and attended by all members. 24. Group training is held regularly, with at least three modules each of two days during this phase to enable all to participate effectively, especially the weaker members (in some cases special modules may have to be conducted for them), to build group culture and to raise the level of
 -93- Annex 4 commitment to mutual support and acceptance of group decisions and of self-confidence in private and public life. Details of the indicative coverage of the training programs are given in Annex 12. 25. Training of SHG Representatives. The two representatives who have been elected need to be trained to conduct meetings, to help the group to establish a supportive culture, to establish a priorities in lending and to impose and accept sanctions. They need to equip themselves with the skills of numeracy and literacy to enable them to keep a check on what is recorded in the minutes and pass books. They need to develop leadership qualities and the confidence to relate with institutions like government departments and banks as well as to provide leadership in organizing common action programs. It is important that the group selects/elects the representatives for the following year at least six months in advance to enable them to build up these skills and confidence. If the group representatives are not changed every year, there is a danger that power will accumulate in the hands of a few which will in turn prevent the effective participation of all members. Rotation of representatives provides all the members with an opportunity to acquire the skills of group leadership. Since the first set of representatives are likely to be the most proficient women in the group, once they have handed over responsibilities they could play the role of group animators, after the groups have been in operation for 12-15 months, taking on some of the supportive roles played hitherto by the NGO worker, provided they have had at least 3-4 modules of training and exposure to operating SHGs. One or two small common action programs in the village are planned and implemented preferably in collaboration with other SHGs if they exist in the village. 26. Gender Issues. Gender issues concerning women and the girl child are raised at meetings and form an important part of training. Men are invited to participate in group exchange and in common action programs and occasionally in SHG meetings. Negative reactions from men to women's absence from home when they attend meetings or are involved in common action or even to the increasing presence and profile of women in public life is a common feature during this period. NGOs have to cope with this problem even offering counseling service in the home when the problem threatens to escalate. 27. Support to the group fund of the SHG. After six to nine months, if the SHG is progressing according to the indicators mentioned above, the group would be linked to a lending institution to provide a line of credit matching the savings of the group (see para 25 above). This helps to build up available capital, enabling members to access larger loans for business, trading and other small income generating activities. 28. Role of NGO and other intervenors. The NGO continues to play a key role in this phase in the training of the groups and group representatives as well as in gender sensitization. As far as the SHGs are concerned, the NGO moves away from direct intervention to support the process of group growth by attending all the meetings of the SHGs and intervening where required. The line departments and other private sector institutions play a direct role in training asset owners and village resource persons. 29. Features of the SHGs at the End of Phase II. These would include: - all the members are engaged in savings;
 -94- Annex 4 loaning is taking place for both consumption and, to a lesser extent, productive purposes; all transactions are supported with documentation; a summary of loans and recoveries is posted in a public place and regularly updated; the group fund is steadily increasing through interest, savings and fund raising by the group; the group's resources have been augmented through obtaining a line of credit to the group from the bank or other lending institution; the group fund is revolving; bank balance is low or nil;. the recovery rate is consistently over 90 percent; attendance is consistently over 80 percent; the members have acquired the skills of literacy and numeracy to conduct meetings and to resolve conflicts; their confidence to act in public life has increased; they are able to relate with other institutions and government as a group; the group has the experience of organizing and being involved in one or two common action programs; and the members have begun to address gender issues and to take small though significant actions both in public and at home. Phase III Growth of self-reliance: 15 months to 36 months - Withdrawal of the NGO 30. The key developments which take place for the SHG during this phase are: - SHG takes over responsibility for managing its own affairs including payment for services required; - Promotion of inter-action between the SHGs within the cluster to facilitate cross- learning and sharing between groups and to develop a more effective power base for the women; - Greater emphasis on economic activities and on improving productivity through technology transfer; - Credit available from bank increases in line with group's credit history and with bank's increased confidence in group's credit management capacity;
 -95- Annex 4 Linkage with other technical agencies for technology transfer, demonstrations, exposure to menus of options for more productive and remunerative income generating activities; 31. Role of intervenors. The intervenors, particularly the NGOs, need to integrate withdrawal into their strategy from the beginning in order that interventions support the growth of self reliant people's institutions and not increase their dependency. Withdrawal becomes more tangible and acceptable after the major interventions required to build up the groups taper off. 32. The process of withdrawal would be gradual and the duration of this phase variable depending on the capacity of the SHGs. It is expected that the process of withdrawal could be substantially completed by the end of the third year after the formation of the group, but in costing the services of the NGOs allowance has been made for some support in the fourth year as a precaution. 33. During the later years of the project, efforts would be made to foster the emergence of inter- group associations at the cluster level and inter-cluster associations, but the need for such bodies and their functions should be decided by the group (see Annex 6 for further details). Experience of apex bodies in Tamil Nadu has shown that they are vulnerable to political influences or are used as steps towards political positions. Politicization of apex bodies weakens and eventually destroys the self help groups. Care should be taken that the groups are strong enough to control the functioning of the apex bodies before they are formed. In some parts of Tamil Nadu, groups have restricted the roles of apex bodies to supervising the groups and assisting in problem solving; they have refused to give apex bodies any funds or the power to control resources. 34. During this period the supportive role of the NGO decreases. It needs, however, to ensure that regular feedback and analysis of data is available in order to identify trends in financial management of the SHGs. A few guidelines given in Attachment 1 relating to the management of savings, the group fund, loans, book-keeping and audit will help the NGO to identify important indicators of the SHGs' performance. E. Strategies for Promotion of SHGs in Areas Without NGO Presence 35. Since NGOs are recognised to be the most effective agents for the mobilization and provision of on-going support to women's SHGs, project activities would start in districts/blocks with strong NGOs who would be contracted by the WDCs to form and sustain the SHGs. However, suitable NGOs, oriented to the concepts of self-reliance and self-help which underpin the SHGs, are not omnipresent. Hence, it will be necessary to develop alternative mechanisms for forming SHGs in areas without NGOs. In such areas, efforts would be made to harness the enthusiasm and commitment of socially motivated people within the community. These are likely to be people who have been campaign workers under other awareness raising programs such as the Total Literacy Campaign (TLC). The WDC and the lead (experienced) NGOs would jointly identify suitable socially motivated field workers 6-12 months in advance of commencement of work in an area devoid of NGOs. After a period of initial training, they would work with the lead NGOs to gain practical field experience for around six months before returning to their "home" areas to start forming SHGs. During the first year
 -96- Annex 4 of their independent operation, the lead NGO would continue to supervise and support their work. In time it is expected that these workers would be able to work independently like other smaller NGOs. Funding required to implement this approach would be channelled through the lead NGOs until the "emerging" NGO starts operating independently. 36. Haryana WDC intends to experiment with a variant of this approach through fostering the formation of a registered society to be managed by a selected number of field workers within the community, particularly those previously actively involved in promoting the TLC. This society, after training in the key elements of the project concept/approach , would take on the responsibility for the formation of SHGs under the overall guidance of the District Project Coordinating Committee and the WDC. It would engage field workers as required. The experience of other strategies involving various community groups in the promotion of SHGs currently being piloted would also be closely watched and evaluated. These would include WEMTOP's experiment with the promotion of SHGs by producer cooperatives linked to the Khadi and Village Industries Commission. F. Inclusion of Existing SHGs 37. The growth path of SHGs outlined above indicates that it takes at least two years before SHG members are likely to become actively involved in investing in income generating activities on a significant scale. At the same time, the accumulation of savings by many SHGs under on-going SHG programs indicates that groups are not readily able to identify potential viable investment opportunities. Hence, this is an area to which the project needs to devote considerable attention. In order to provide an early opportunity to promote income generating activities, as well as the development of inter-group clusters/associations, the project would benefit from the inclusion of some existing SHGs formed by NGOs. These groups would need to be consistent with the project concept. To this end, the following criteria would be used to screen existing SHGs for inclusion in the project: - the group constitutes a democratically managed affinity group which conforms to the general principles of SHGs outlined above; - the group is involved in the management of savings and credit; - the group is orientated towards self-reliance; - the group exhibits a high degree of group cohesion and stability and constitutes a good group as measured by such indicators as high degree of attendance at meetings, participation of all members in group discussions and decision making and regularity of savings; demonstration of sound credit management including high degree of internal loaning and rotation of savings, and high repayment rate (above 90 percent); linkage with bank providing resources for investment in income generating activities; readiness to undertake income generating activities; and
 -97- Annex 4 group is sponsored by a project partner NGO which has been trained in the promotion of business development. 38. Other criteria to be taken into consideration relate to the sponsoring NGO and would include: - Existing SHGs are attached to NGOs which have been contracted to form new SHGs and are located in or adjacent to areas of the district selected for implementation of the project; - The NGOs which have promoted the SHGs should perceive SHGs as an important means of women's empowerment and should be giving priority attention to SHG work (in terms of staff time, training, and resources); - in order to facilitate formation of clusters of SHGs, the existing SHGs should be located in close geographical proximity; and - the NGO should agree to work on the components which it may not have pursued to date, particularly business support inputs, and promotion of clusters/associations. 39. Existing SHGs would be evaluated for inclusion in the project by the NGOs and verified by the WDC District Project Manager. "Adopted" existing SHGs would, however, not exceed 30 percent of the anticipated number of SHGs to be managed in any state program. 40. Groups formed under other programs such as Mahila Samakhya, DWCRA and TLC are unlikely to meet these criteria. These groups tend to be large, lack homogeneity and affinity and are not constituted as self-help groups. Thus, it may not be appropriate to incorporate them wholesale into the project. The project may benefit from the awareness raising and mobilization efforts of these programs but it is likely that potential SHGs would only emerge as sub-sets from within these groups. G. Promotion of SHGs by Mature SHGs 41. In order to promote the wider replication of SHGs in a more cost effective and sustainable manner, the project would enable mature SHGs to promote the formation of additional SHGs. Experience of other NGO programs indicates that stabilized mature SHGs have a powerful demonstration effect within the locality and frequently women in neighbouring villages express a desire to form an SHG. These women should first be encouraged to visit the mature group and learn of their experiences. It is at this point that the members of the new group assess their own capability, perceive problem areas and satisfy their queries. The potential new SHG would then request assistance from a representative of the mature SHG in establishing the new SHG. Whilst the representatives from the mature SHG can provide general guidance and support, training inputs for the new SHG from the NGO are likely to be required, at least initially. Over time, however, the project would train members from mature SHGs who show leadership qualities and communication skills as trainers. The project would seek to form one training team of members from mature SHGs from each cluster of villages. These training teams would be instrumental in spreading the SHG concept and forming SHGs on a wider scale in their locality. The NGO's role would be to strengthen the capacity of the cluster and the existing groups to facilitate this process through various leadership and capacity building programs.

(d) Attending all group meetings for the first 9-12 months after which, according to the strength of the group, attendance can be reduced but should be at least once per month for the first two years. (e) Providing initial training of group members and group representatives by the NGO training team and the provision of follow-up training to group members at regular group meetings. (f) Maintaining the group accounts and minutes for first 12 months (if no suitable person from within the group or community can be found initially), and training of a group member or local person to maintain the accounts thereafter. (g) Auditing group accounts half-yearly in the first year and thereafter annually. (h) Assisting women in the selection of appropriate income generating activities through participatory processes.

It is estimated that one trainer would be able to provide the initial training to 20 SHGs per year. The changing nature of the role of the NGO will also require inputs from different types of staff. Thus although the intensity of inputs to the SHG would reduce, the involvement of higher cost staff may mean that there is no significant change in the overall cost of servicing the SHGs. Given the broad-ranging support to be provided by the NGO staff it is expected that participating NGOs would recruit incremental staff with appropriate expertise and provide necessary additional training before taking charge of groups at various stages. The NGOs would also provide the necessary supervisory staff to oversee implementation at the field level.  -109- Annex 6 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT SHG CLUSTERS AND ASSOCIATIONS Rationale 1. The formation of clusters of SHGs (CGs) and associations of clusters (ACs) at appropriate levels can play an important role in the sustainability of the SHGs and the wider replication of the SHG concept. Such representative bodies can provide the on-going support and linkages which the SHGs require, whilst also being responsible for promoting the formation and nurturing of further SHGs. This would contribute towards significantly reducing the social intermediation costs involved in group development and make the whole process of expanding the SHG concept more cost effective and replicable. Over time, these bodies can take over most of the ftunctions performed by the NGOs and hence they provide a sound basis for withdrawal of NGO support. CGs/ACs also represent a useful feature of the empowerment process broadening the power base of women in addressing issues that affect them in a democratic manner. Lessons Learnt from Past Experience 2. Limited experience has been gained to date by a number of NGOs in the forrnation of CGs/ACs both in the project states, (with the exception of Haryana) and elsewhere in the country. This has highlighted a number of important lessons which are likely to be important factors in the development of CGs/ACs. The key factors in the formation of CGs/ACs are summarized below: (a) it is essential that CGs/ACs emerge naturally based on demand generated from the SHGs as they come to appreciate the utility and importance of these bodies and are in a position to control them. If the foundations of the SHGs are laid well through providing opportunities for inter-action between groups e.g. through joint trainings of group members and representatives and member conferences, this process is likely to occur; (b) identifying and training the leaders who are ready to motivate is important for sustaining the momentum; (c) the closer the geographic proximity of the groups, (involving little of no transport costs), the greater the chances of their coming together; (d) SHGs should be located in the service area of a bank branch which helps to strengthen further linkages with the lending institution;
 -110- Annex 6 (e) CGs/ACs must fix their own criteria for membership and admission procedures - in general, only a group that is stable and working well can join; (f) member groups should pay an admission fee and annual regular contribution to cover operating costs; (g) the size of CGs consisting of 15-20 SHGs (200-500 members) and ACs of 4-8 clusters (60-160 SHGs) has been found effective; (h) the process of forming an AC needs to be approached with caution as there are dangers in these larger bodies becoming politicized, particularly if they become financial institutions; and (i) the formation of clusters can be expected to start within the first 18-30 months after the formation of the SHGs. The ACs would come up at a later stage - after 3-4 years. Roles of CGs/ACs 4. CGs/ACs can play a variety of functions depending on demand and capacity to provide effective support in areas ranging from providing a forum for collective action and promoting awareness building and collective learning to supplying services or acting as a financial intermediary. Some of the important functions which these bodies can perform can be broadly categorized as follows: A. Sharing of Experiences and Collective Action (i) collective knowledge building and leadership (ii) supporting weak groups (iii) solving of inter-group and intra-group disputes/problems (iv) promoting new groups (v) training of SHG members/leaders in running of SHGs; (vi) monitoring SHGs' progress towards empowerment of its members (vii) lobbying for policy changes and resource mobilisation (government funds, schemes, bank funds) (viii) promoting representation of SHGs in appropriate fora B. Management of Business Activities and Provision of Technical and Marketing Services (i) business activities such as purchase of inputs/raw materials and marketing to benefit from economies of scale, either directly or through promoting business associations or producer groups among members in the CG/AC engaged in the same on-farm or non-farm activity; (ii) training in business promotion activities (e.g. market surveys, costing, designing);
 -1 11 - Annex 6 C. Provision of Financial Services1 (i) audit facilities; (ii) inter-group lending of surplus funds generated by some groups to member groups wishing to borrow additional funds; (iii) financial intermediary on behalf of banks, receiving larger loans to be passed on as smaller loans to the member SHGs; and (iv) provision of specific purpose saving and credit services. D. Provision of Social Services (i) management of certain community services (creche, maintenance of drinking water supply); and (ii) provision of social security schemes e.g. life insurance, cattle insurance, health care, economic security schemes for women. 5. The roles mentioned in sections B, C and D demand a higher level of expertise than the roles mentioned in section A. These different roles can be played at either the Cluster or Association of Cluster level. The role which each CG/AC will perform will be deternined by demand and the capacity of the human resources available and would depend on: (i) strength of the member groups (ii) leadership available to the cluster/association of clusters (iii) socio-economic conditions in which the SHGs are working (iv) vision of the groups and of the NGOs promoting them (v) expertise and resources available with the NGOs or the capacity to access resources Financing of CGs/ACs 6. The level of costs incurred to maintain a CG/AC depends on the roles performed which in turn determines the complement of staff which a CG/AC requires. For sustainability, mechanisms for covering the costs through annual contributions, service fees, or comrnission need to be established from the outset. However, these charges have to be set at a level which enables individual SHGs/members to derive a benefit. The roles described in section A can largely be handled by the CG/AC representatives on a voluntary basis. CGs/ACs acting as financial intermnediaries, although requiring a higher and more professional level of staffing (2-3 staff including 1 professional and 1 accountant), have a ready mechanism for cost recovery through the interest margin. With a volume of lending of Rs. 5 million and an interest margin of 6-9%, such a CG/AC can be self-sufficient. Careful analysis of the cost of funds and potential lending terms would be required to be undertaken by any CG/AC intending to act as a financial intermediary to The project would insist on strict external audit procedures for any CGs/ACs functioning as financial intermediaries
 -112- Annex 6 ensure that an adequate interest spread would be available to cover costs. CGs/ACs providing commercial services, such as inputs supply would need to charge commission to cover the costs of making the arrangements. Covering the costs of technical and social services through charges may initially be more difficult but there is increasing evidence that SHG members are willing to pay for services which they find useful. Role of NGOs in Promoting CGs/ACs 7. The role of the NGO is very crucial in facilitating the emergence of CGs/ACs. Although the initial motivation must come from the SHG members, thereafter the SHGs need support and guidance from the NGOs to operationalize the concept. The orientation of the NGOs is also important as it is essential that the NGOs have confidence in the SHG members' ability to promote and maintain cluster and association structures. They must be ready to see that their functions reduce year by year and the SHGs have freedom to take intiative so that CGs/ACs become an effective part of a gradual withdrawal strategy. Project Interventions 8. Development of Guidelines for the Formation of CGs/ACs The project would promote the emergence of CGs/ACs on a pilot scale, commencing in those states where existing mature SHGs are to be inducted into the project, principally UP and Kamataka. This work is expected to commence during the second year of project implementation. The study would focus on the pros and cons of the different roles which the CGs/ACs can play; the institutional framework including staffing and organizational procedures required in relation to the different roles; possible financing arrangements to ensure cost recovery and sustainability; and the inputs required for capacity building of the CGs/ACs including training, expert guidance and back-up support. Terms of reference for the study are given in Attachment 1. The guidelines are not intended to be prescriptive but to establish a framework of the essential organizational features required for the operation of CGs/ACs performing different functions within which the modus operandi can evolve to meet the specific needs of different groups of SHGs. 9.  -115- Annex 7 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT MOBILIZATION OF FUNDS BY SHGs A. Credit and the Rural Poor 1. Despite the vast expansion of the formal credit structure in India, the dependence of the rural poor on moneylenders continues,1 especially for meeting emergency credit requirements. Some of the major causes lie in the difficulties formal institutions face in dealing effectively and economically with a large number of small borrowers who require credit frequently and in small quantities; limitations imposed by the legal framework on their operations and bankers' perceptions of the risks and creditworthiness of these borrowers. Such dependence is even more pronounced in the case of women in view of the additional constraints imposed by gender discrimination. The major social factors which hinder women's access to formal credit include their low level of literacy and numeracy, their general lack of exposure and contact with the world outside their immediate environs, unfamiliarity with bureaucratic procedures and the unsympathetic attitudes of bank functionaries. Women's access is also limited by high borrower transaction costs and lack of collateral. Women's demand for credit requires a system which allows them to engage in risk-averse, multi-production strategies, provides for small loans with the minimum of procedures and allows repayment of loans in frequent, small installments. 2. To overcome these hurdles, thrift and credit Self-Help Groups (SHGs) have been promoted, particularly among women.2 These groups initially draw on their own accumulated savings to provide loans principally to meet consumption and emergency needs, thereby removing women from exploitation by moneylenders. As a credit delivery system, SHGs bring the benefits of flexibility and responsiveness to the needs of the borrower. They act as both moneylender, advancing small loans quickly, and development banker, providing small amounts of production credit, whilst following the principles of participation and mutual cooperation. SHGs enable women to gain experience of managing credit and to leam credit discipline. However, the ability of SHGs to meet the financial needs of their members rapidly outgrows the limitations of their own resources. In recognition of this, the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) has spearheaded systems to link the SHGs with the formal credit system. Around 63% of households depend on informal sources of credit - these are predominantly poor, non- cultivator households - All India Debt and Investment Survey (1981-82) 2 Details on the functioning of SHGs are given in Annex 4
 -116- Annex 7 B. Role of SHGs in Accessing Institutional Credit 3. After initial hesitancy, the formal financial sector is gradually recognizing the importance of linking SHGs with their own operations. Linking SHGs with banks has been shown to be a cost-effective, transparent and flexible approach to improve the accessibility of credit from the formal banking system to the unreached rural poor. Lending to SHGs offers the banks a much needed solution to the twin problems being faced by banks, viz., recovery of loans in rural areas and the high transaction costs of dealing with small borrowers at frequent intervals. The provision of credit through SHGs reduces the direct transaction costs of the banks by 40-60 percent as a major task of appraisal, supervision and recovery of the loan is taken over by the group itself. However, the major contributory factor is the improvement in the recovery rate. Repayment rates of loans to SHGs are around 95 percent compared with recovery rates on individual loans to the target group under the poverty alleviation programs such as the Integrated Rural Development Program (IRDP) of 30-50 percent. As shown in Attachment 1, the total transaction costs of the banks (including default risk) are reduced from 34 percent when lending to individuals to 11 percent when lending to SHGs.3 4. The transaction costs for the borrowers are also substantially reduced through being able to access credit in the village without having to make several time consuming journeys to the bank branch. Studies have indicated the overall reduction in the borrower's transaction costs to be 85 percent. C. NABARD Initiative 5. Pilot program. To foster this approach, NABARD launched a pilot program in 1992 for linking the SHGs with the banks. This followed the issue of instructions by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in July 1991 which allow banks to finance informal and unregistered groups without collateral whilst giving SHGs the liberty to decide their own terms and conditions for financial transactions. Banks are increasingly getting involved in financing SHGs. The pilot program achieved considerable success and has covered around 5,000 groups as against the original target of 500 SHGs The repayment performance of the loans taken by the groups has been more than 95 percent. Eighty percent of the groups were formed by women. 6. Future directions. Encouraged by the success of the pilot program, RBI has made financing of SHGs by the banks a part of their general priority sector lending. Banks are being encouraged by RBI to treat the linkage program as a business opportunity for reaching the rural poor and to make it part of their corporate strategy. The guidelines issued in April 1996 formalise some of the innovations which have been developed during the pilot phase to simplify procedures. In particular, the guidelines make provision for banks to provide cash credit limits4 3 'Transaction Costs of Lending to the Rural Poor; Non-governmental organizations and Self-help Groups of the poor as intermediaries for banks in India': V. The guidelines also remove many of the doubts in the minds of bankers and set proper procedures and documentation for SHG financing. Adherence to the service area is not mandatory and SHGs/NGOs may deal with a branch other than the service area branch. The instructions issued by RBI clarify the situation regarding defaulters, assuring the banks that the defaults by a few members of SHGs and/or their family members to the financing banks should not ordinarily come in the way of financing the SHG, provided the SHG itself is not in default to the bank. However, the bank loan may not be utilized by the SHG for financing a defaulter member to the bank. NABARD's support for training of banks' staff as well as 100 percent refinancing has been assured. The RBI instructions encourage the banks (commercial banks, regional rural banks and cooperative banks5) to step up their credit to the unreached rural poor by extensively using the SHG route. D. Lessons Learnt and Continuing Constraints 7. The experience to date indicates that SHGs provide an effective mechanism for demonstrating that the poor are bankable. The repayment rate on bank loans of over 90 percent indicates that SHGs have the ability to manage credit and to impose credit discipline. The credit and recovery performance of SHGs are better, as loans availed by members are self-chosen and small-size manageable loans; credit is available in a timely manner; and loans availed by members are need-based. At the same time, the close-knit nature of the group ensures proper utilization of loans and peer pressure for repayment. 8. However, despite the clear indications of success, a number of constraints still remain. Despite the issue of guidelines and circulars, information does not always filter down to the bank branches and many branch managers are still unaware of the scheme or do not fully understand the flexibility it provides in lending to SHGs. Hence, continued effort is required to orient both senior level bank management, particularly Regional Managers, and branch managers and to train them in the provisions and procedures of the scheme. Even where bankers are aware of the scheme, there is a need to instill confidence in the mechanism through facilitating contact with existing SHGs which have been successfully linked with banks. E. Project Interventions 9. Mobilization of Funds. The project would assist SHG members to mobilize funds for consumption and investment through inculcating the habit of savings and helping the groups to access external sources of funds to augment their own resources in order to be able to meet the needs of their members. To this end, the SHGs would be linked with banks to access credit at market rates of interest preferably using the simplified flexible procedures offered by the cash credit limit arrangements. 5 The participation of cooperative banks depends on the provision of the state cooperative laws/rules in regard to financing informal groups and at present only Bihar amongst the participating states has this provision.

F. Implementation Arrangements 12. Management of credit funds. The SHGs' savings and credit operations would commence with generation of funds from the members' savings and internal loaning based on these funds in order to establish a track record for sound credit management. Approximately 6- 12 months after formation, efforts would be made to link SHGs with a bank through establishing cash credit limit arrangements. This system enables groups to establish a line of credit from the bank up to an agreed limit, initially equivalent to their own savings, which they can draw on as required for consumption and/or other purposes. This approach provides group members easy access to bank credit with the minimum of processing formalities and restrictions on the use of funds. The cash credit limit is gradually raised as a proportion of the group's savings, generally up to a limit of 4 times, in line with the improving credit record of the group. In the UP experience, SHGs have on average been sanctioned cash credit limits after the group has been in existence for nine months. To simplify the procedures, the banks have sanctioned telescopic limits on the basis of thirty six months savings and in a ratio of 1:4 and the banks revise the
 -119- Annex 7 withdrawal limit on a quarterly basis. In this way repeated revisions of the documentation are avoided which minimizes expenditure and inconvenience to the group members. The cash credit system is more beneficial to the groups than a term loan as the group only pays interest on the amount of credit which it draws whilst with a term loan, the group is liable to pay interest on the whole amount sanctioned irrespective of whether the group is able to utilize the money immediately or not. Experience from UP indicates that interaction with bank staff on an individual basis would be beneficial in encouraging the participation of banks in financing SHGs and expediting adoption of the cash credit limit arrangements. Over time the group may decide to switch to a group term loan or it may prefer to continue with the cash credit limit arrangements. 13. Wherever SHGs are unable to access this facility from a bank, they may be provided with funds from other financial institutions provided that the terms and conditions are consistent with market interest rates charged to the SHGs and the SHGs able to deternine the interest rate to be charged to their members. Key features of SHGs' lending operations. Based on past experience with SHGs in India, it is anticipated that the initial uses of credit would be for consumption, social and health needs. This slowly shifts towards productive investment. The limited available data indicate clearly defined trends in the pattern of lending by SHGs although the dimensions vary considerably between groups depending on their circumstances. A broad-based study conducted by NABARD revealed that while in the first year around 70-80 percent of the SHG credit goes for consumption purposes and the remaining 20-30 percent for production and investment needs, by the third year the position is reversed with consumption credit forming only 20-30 percent and credit for productive purposes increasing to 70-80 percent.9 Data available on a sample of the MYRADA sponsored groups indicates a similar trend with loans for consumption decreasing from 46 percent of the number of loans granted (for SHGs less than 2 years old) to 26 percent (for SHGs 3-5 years old).  -127- Annex 8 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT WOMEN'S PARTICIPATION IN ON-FARM ACTIVITIES Strategy 1. Experience of existing SHGs indicates that over 50 percent of the credit is used for agriculture - for improved inputs (seeds, fertilizer), and small livestock. Investments in on-farm activities would target three categories of women: (a) landless women with access to small amounts of land around the homestead; (b) women with access to both homestead and field land who are currently engaged in subsistence production; and (c) women with land who are already engaged in cash crop production. 2. Women would be assisted first to consolidate the food security base of the household and then embark on a growth path through improvements in crop and animal productivity and onto diversification. This work would begin with activities that increase the sustainability of predominantly rainfed agriculture through the introduction of improved land and water conservation activities. As group members progressively wish to optimize returns from limited resources, extension support would be provided to introduce activities with potential for greater economic realization such as cultivation of herbs, spices, fruits, vegetables and floriculture. To minimize risk, only known technologies, which the women and their families have been unable to access, would be promoted. Attempts would also be made to introduce the women into market processes and other activities, e.g., storage, grading and packing, that add value to the basic agricultural cycle. 3. Livestock activities would focus on sheep and goats in small units which can be easily managed by women alongside their other work. Necessary support would include the dissemination of improved feeding practices and greater emphasis on fodder production and animal health. 4. To improve the terms on which women participate in markets, the project would encourage the formation, later in the life of the project, of inter-SHG commodity groups/producer associations focused on the production, processing and marketing of one product and its by-products with SHGs taking responsibility for the running costs. Women would also be introduced to new technology which could help to reduce the drudgery involved in many agricultural tasks and food preparation. 5. Potential investment opportunities. Given the wide variations in the resource base across the project states and districts, the specific opportunities open to women will be location specific . Hence, the project approach for land-based activities will necessarily have to be flexible to accommodate local needs. In general, separate lines of action would be required for semi-arid rainfed and largely rainfed areas (e.g., Panchmahals, Kolar, Chitradurga, and
 -128- Annex 8 Hoshangabad) and for better endowed areas (e.g., Muzuffarpur, Sehore, Sabarkantha and Ranchi). An indication of possible opportunities in the initial project districts is given below: (a) Bihar. In dry areas, emphasis would be on moisture conservation measures; expanding irrigation through water storage ponds and lift irrigation; improving the productivity of homestead gardens; small animal management; post-harvesting value addition; and access to larger markets through group marketing. Wasteland is available in the hinterland of villages which could provide opportunities for group- managed horticulture (guava, mango). (b) Gujarat. In Panchmahals, the primary action required is in-situ soil and moisture conservation followed by improving the productivity of the traditional crop cycles through green manuring, mulching and composting to ensure food security. For income generation, dryland horticulture (ber/lac, amla, custard apple) with garlic and ginger production and processing on homesteads and small animal management for egg and meat production are possible starting points. (c) Haryana. Assured moisture in the rainfed areas will allow farmers to tap flower and vegetable markets in Delhi, in addition to focusing on traditional cereals, oilseed crops and potatoes. Tapping specialist and non-traditional markets such as organic produce and cheeses offer other possibilities. (d) Karnataka. Most of the project area is characterised by low rainfall, poor irrigation and inferior degraded soils.  -135- Annex 9 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT SUPPORT FOR NON-FARM INCOME GENERATING ACTIVITIES A. Objectives 1. The objective of this component of the project is to raise the level of women's involvement in non-farm activities from subsistence to more profitable levels; facilitate new entrants in starting income generation activities; and facilitate skill and capacity building including the development of abilities in decision making and management of resources. Women will have different priorities in taking up non-farm activities ranging from those viewing an income generating activity as a supplementary source of income to those with the ability to establish a more complex micro-enterprise activity as a full time occupation and primary source of income, requiring a higher level of business skills. Assistance provided under the project would need to accommodate these diverse needs. B. Constraints 2. Past efforts to promote non-farm activities have frequently failed as the selection of activities has been production, rather than market-driven, and training has frequently been provided in isolation from linkages with finance, production technology and market opportunities. Other constraints experienced include the difficulty of identifying financially viable activities; inadequate processes for training potential entrepreneurs particularly from amongst poor women; confusion of welfare and business objectives on the part of facilitators; lack of regular support to entrepreneurs after the initial launch of the activity and weaknesses in technology transfer, product development and marketing. Particular factors constraining the promotion of non-farm activities amongst poor women include: (a) Women have problems in getting access to credit due to lack of ownership of land and property that can be used as collateral. Timely availability and adequacy of finance are critical. (b) Low levels of literacy. (c) Lack of knowledge with regard to bookkeeping and accounts. (d) Rigid mind sets, paternalistic behavior and lack of gender sensitivity of the line agencies. Hence the need to sensitize them to gender and poverty issues.
 -136- Annex 9 (e) Lack of familiarity with the external environment beyond the village thereby limiting mobility. (f) Lack of confidence in dealing with officials in the districts and in sector-based corporations resulting in poor access to existing infrastructure. (g) Most of the women in the target group are at or below subsistence level. There is no room for making incorrect choices as the costs of failure are very high. Hence the importance of appropriate guidance from the initial stages of the program. (h) In cases where the raw material is provided to groups of women and the product is marketed by an intervening agency, the women are far from empowered: (i) The women remain at the level of wage Labour and perhaps graduate to piece rate work. (ii) Payment levels are extremely low and there is a sense of exploitation as well as dependency. (iii) The agency may not have marketing know-how and the women are blamed for inventory pile-up. (iv) There is no link between the women and the customer so no feed back for the women producers regarding quality/market need. (v) Complete dependency of the women's groups on the agency. Hence the importance of providing entrepreneurship training and skills to the self- help groups. (i) NGOs may not have skills in identifying appropriate activities for income generation. Hence the need to provide this orientation as well as involve organizations/individuals with entrepreneurship skills as resource agencies for business identification, market surveys, skill provision, follow-up and back-up trouble shooting. (j) If credit is taken for developing new skills or activities without ensuring adequate market demand the risk is high. C. Approach 3. To counteract these weaknesses, the approach adopted under the project emphasizes the identification of potentially profitable activities in a specific location based on raw materials, existing skills and market opportunities specific to that location. Non-farm activities would be
 -137- Annex 9 selected by the women, based on individual choice. Production could be at the individual or group level. Selection would be from a wide range of production, trading and service activities. The project would expose the women to a range of market determined traditional and non-traditional income generating activities through participatory action around a menu of options of feasible economic activities. 4. Experience indicates that it is easier to build on existing skills and familiar products than to introduce new products/activities and develop new skills. Similarly, it is easier for the target group to market their goods locally than seek marketing opportunities in distant urban markets. Hence, the identification process should follow a sequential approach, starting with examining the scope for the easiest activities/products to be promoted, based on existing skills and local resources and markets, before moving towards the more difficult areas of the introduction of new products and new skills. Such an approach would suggest the following hierarchy of activities for analysis: (a) expansion of traditional activities in the project area which offer growth prospects; (b) identification of existing products for which there is a deficiency of supply in local markets; and (c) identification of new products in fast growing sectors so that production from the project area is fulfilling incremental demand rather than competing with existing producers who have a head start. 5. The activities in which rural women are typically engaged can be divided into six broad groups of activities. (a) Trading activities such as vending vegetables, fish, milk, and fruits, breaking bulk and grading or sorting. (b) Activities based on traditional skills and using local raw materials such as leaf plate making, brooms, embroidery, bead work, making ropes, mats, bamboo products, laces, pandal making, durrie weaving, fabric weaving, pottery, etc. (c) Production and trade in processed foods such as parboiled rice, jams, jellies, fruit bars, papads, honey, bread, biscuits, snacks, tamarind powder, spices, salt, etc. (d) Non-traditional activities such as making cards, notebooks, files, envelopes and raising broiler chickens. (e) Traditional service activities such as running small hotels, provision stores and tea stalls or hiring out bicycles or utensils. (f) Skill-based non-traditional service activities such as hand pump repair, radio repair, running STD booths, cycle repair, photography, plumbing, welding, zip repair, etc. 6. Substantial improvement in the returns from any of these activities is possible with marginal interventions. For instance, women in trading activities such as vegetable vending could benefit substantially from access to timely and adequate credit on commercial terms. Credit

Similarly linkages could be established with larger markets thereby enabling higher net returns. Access to credit for purchase of a bicycle or push cart would reduce the drudgery of carrying head loads to the market and increase the number of villages covered. 7. Similarly women using traditional skills in embroidery, leaf plate making, durrie weaving, pottery, etc., could benefit from interventions pertaining to design and color combinations, thread quality, technology and tools and marketing as also from the availability of cheaper credit than moneylenders.
