SOCIAL ASSESSMENT 2. Participatory approaches are central to (a) the identification of the project's target group; (b) the micro-level planning envisaged in the project, particularly for enterprise development and the social components, which will involve eliciting views and preferred development options; and (c) overall implementation of the project. In effect, the project concept and approach are themselves a continuous process of social assessment which will occur throughout implementation, as they are highly participatory and demand driven. For example: - Implementing NGOs will be selected by the WDCs in consultation with village women, other residents and leaders, and district officials, thus ensuring that they are acceptable to all. * The selection of "target beneficiaries" by the NGOs involved in group formation would involve social assessment processes. The NGOs will know the villages in which they work and engage their communities in identifying target households. While nurturing the SHGs, the NGOs will consult with communities widely about what problems the community/women have experienced which need to be addressed during implementation, what program/infrastructure linkages need to be strengthened in the particular village, what micro-enterprises are acceptable to the women, and so on. During these processes, the NGOs will also become aware of the need for and appropriate strategies to implement aspects of the program such as gender sensitization, awareness creation, etc. * The group formation and maturing process itself entails a constant sharing of experiences, analysis of needs, strategies, and outcomes by group members and implementing agencies. * The SHGs would be involved in a number of activities which ensure that their views as well as those of their village communities are taken into account during project implementation. These include participatory training activities, community consultations for the purposes of determining what community assets need to be created, and self-assessment techniques used during monitoring and evaluation to assess the performance and impact of the project and promote sustainability.
 -157- Annex 10 3. Therefore, while no fonnal social assessment "study" has taken place, other than the assessments described in Annex 15 for tribal populations, project preparation and appraisal processes identified the wide range of stakeholders described above, obtained their views, and carried out social analysis. A number of significant issues which were identified have been taken into account in project design. For example: * Concern was expressed that the project should not focus only on women below the poverty line. Haryana, for example, is a state with a relatively high per capita income and a low percentage of people below the poverty line, and it is clear that even women above the poverty line are severely disadvantaged socially. Alternative approaches were discussed widely. Consequently, the project proposes to concentrate economic activities on the poor, but has developed small sub-components (such as awareness creation) which will reach out to other disadvantaged women and address their needs. * In some areas, the friction between panchayats and field NGOs creates the risk of a powerful force of "negative stakeholders". It was agreed that in order to reduce such potential tension during project implementation, the WDCs would ensure that the implementing NGOs have the full support of local self-government groups as well as of potential beneficiaries. This would be done through a village level consultation process. In addition, panchayats and other community members would be oriented fully to the project concept and its approaches. Further, conflict resolution will be an important aspect of the training imparted to the NGOs, SHGs, etc. Another potential group of negative stakeholders are me in the communities, who may resent the project for its empowering effects on women. A consequence of this resentment is often increased domestic or community violence against women. The project plans to include gender sensitization as a community activity, and will increase women's awareness of their rights. In addition, the solidarity achieved among women through group formation and action would assist women in dealing with this problem individually and collectively. III. MACRO-INDICATORS OF SOCIAL STATUS IN THE PROJECT DISTRICTS 4. The project will be implemented in selected districts of six states, numbering 35 in all. The districts have been chosen, firstly, on the basis of poverty criteria, viz. the percentage of population below the poverty line (BPL), sex ratio, female literacy rate, and percentage of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (SC/ST) in the population. The main reason for use of poverty criteria is that the project aims to improve the economic and social situation of poor women in areas where their opportunities have thus far been limited. In some states, such as Bihar and Madhya Pradesh, the selected districts represent substantially different geo-cultural zones. A reason for such representation is that, in time, expansion of the project to a much larger program would be facilitated if success can be shown to have been achieved in a variety of settings. In
 -158- Annex 10 addition, district selection has also taken into account the availability of NGOs to implement the project. 5. The states and districts selected represent a range of different social situations. Female literacy levels in the districts range from 7 percent in Tikamgarh, M.P., to 50 percent in Bharuch, Gujarat. The districts' sex ratios, representing the overall survival of females relative to males, vary from 818 to 1007. The poor comprise a high proportion of the population in Bharuch and Panchmahals, Gujarat, and in Betul, M.P., as represented by the percentage of the population who are SC/ST, but are as low as 12 percent in Surendranagar, Gujarat. Although these macro- indicators are not likely to be significantly impacted by the project during its five-year duration, because the coverage of each district by the project will be limited, they are, nevertheless, important indicators of the status of women in the project areas. 6. The key target group for the project is women below the poverty line, defined by the Government of India as an income of Rs. 11,000 per household (consisting of an average of 5.5 persons) in rural areas. Most women in this category are likely to be from landless households, or small or marginal farm households. Emphasis will be placed on including women who are heads of households, who are among the most severely disadvantaged. Many of these poor women face a multiplicity of adverse circumstances: not only are their economic situations strained, but they are also faced with eking out livings under constraints of infrastructure (in part on account of the areas in which they live), low access to technologies for work or drudgery-reduction, poor access to social services, and heavy family responsibilities. IV. KEY SOCIAL ISSUES AND RELATED PROJECT ACTIONS 7. A number of issues which are related to the project's objectives, concept and approach are raised by the social indicators in the project areas. These are discussed below, along with descriptions of how the project addresses them. A. Literacy 8. In most of the project districts, female literacy is lower than the national average and the average of the state in which the district lies. This is to be expected since the districts were chosen on the basis of poverty criteria, and female literacy is generally well correlated with poverty. Similarly, at the level of blocks and villages selected for implementation, female literacy is low, and there are likely to be very few literate women in the majority of Self Help Groups which are formed. 9. Experience elsewhere in the country (e.g., in the IFAD-supported project in Dharmapuri, Tamil Nadu, as well as in projects implemented by a number of NGOs, some of which will be involved in this project) has shown that low (or virtually no) literacy among group members is a severe constraint to the development of group activities. In particular, group members find it difficult to keep accounts, to access services which require the filling of forms including bank
 -159- Annex 10 services, or even to monitor their savings. As a result they become dependent on the individual who maintains their books and accounts. Consequently it was felt that providing group members basic "functional" literacy is critical to the success of the project, and hence should be a project component. Acquisition of functional literacy skills by SHG members would facilitate the working of the groups broadly, including the maintenance of accounts and records, enabling women to take on leadership responsibilities, and facilitating access to information for both economic and social development. 10. Accordingly, the project has made provisions for the SHGs to acquire functional literacy skills building on what has been achieved through other programs, harnessing resources (personnel, material and financial) available under other schemes such as the total literacy/adult literacy activities of government or even non-governmental agencies in the area, and supplementing them where necessary to strengthen their focus on project-related literacy and numeracy skills. The literacy teaching would be provided only when group members express a demand for it, and the group is willing to bear the cost of sustaining the activity, if necessary, beyond the 18-month period which is deemed a reasonable time for group members to acquire functional literacy. The groups would plan and organize literacy classes in collaboration with the implementing NGO. A tutor would be chosen from among group members or other community residents who have appropriate qualifications. The project would provide for training/retraining of tutors before commencement of classes, and for a nominal honorarium for them. Purchase of teacher and learner materials and miscellaneous equipment would also be financed, as well as the costs incurred by the NGOs managing the activity. Specialist NGOs may be engaged by WDCs to carry out the activity where necessary. 11. In areas where the Total Literacy Campaigns have been concluded successfully, post-literacy activities could be supported, if necessary, or supplemented, if on-going. A special need related specifically to the project's credit and micro-enterprise activities is the development of teaching-learning materials for accounting and business purposes. Under the project, organizations which have specialized capabilities in this field will be engaged to collate/develop and produce materials in the local languages. Post-literacy materials would be suitably modified. By the end of the project, it is expected that the SHGs formed would have sufficient literacy among their members to function smoothly and to feel they have been empowered through its acquisition. 12. In some states, such as Haryana, other special needs arise in the context of functional literacy because of very adverse social conditions affecting women. Haryana is particularly interested in creating awareness of the legal and familial rights of women on account of widespread violence against them, as well as of underlying social problems such as alcohol abuse and drug addiction. Consequently, the functional literacy component will encompass such awareness creation. B. Access to Health Services 13. The project districts are also characterised by poor health among their populations. The poverty of these districts is synonymous with (a) greater susceptibility of their populations to
 -160- Annex 10 illness on account of the major common infections, including childhood infections; (b) poor health among women, especially anemia, which reduces women's capacities to work and makes them greatly susceptible to illness, maternal mortality, and pregnancy and infant loss; and (c) underdevelopment of the public health care infrastructure, including a lack of facilities, staff and supplies, as well as poor private health services. Access to health services is poor as the government health system, which is structured to provide a facility for each cluster of 4-5 villages, is often non-functional in many backward areas. Similarly, access to private health services is often minimal as "modem" medical practitioners prefer to practise in towns or large, better-off villages. Even traditional practitioners are increasingly becoming "urbanized", leaving poor rural populations to the less trained. 14. All these problems represent major constraints to the development of women's economic status and the improvement of household well-being. Greater illness among household members and children means that adult women spend more time caring for sick members of their households. It also places a greater burden on both women and children to work, in order that household income is assured in the event that the male head of household falls ill. Where illnesses such as tuberculosis and malaria have debilitated adult male members of households, women are often the effective heads of households, and face a heavy double burden. In addition, neglect of their own health or illness, particularly if their households are dependent on their earnings, initiates a further downward spiral - loss of wages, poor and worsening nutrition on account of household poverty, greater debility and further diminished work capacity. 15. It is well established that illness is a major cause of indebtedness (to moneylenders) among poor families throughout the country. Women members of thrift and credit groups often report that they borrow from group savings to pay the costs of health care. Health emergencies are particularly devastating. Consumption loans, also, are often taken because the illness of a chief wage eamer has reduced household income to the point where even basic food requirements cannot be met. 16. Several NGOs working with women's self help groups (e.g., SEWA and Utthan in Gujarat, and Adithi in Bihar) have found that providing basic health care that is easily accessible to women and low cost is effective in releasing poor households from the vicious cycle of low economic status and ill-health. Where groups are spread out geographically, and health facilities are distant, the most common approach has been to train village-level health workers to provide basic preventive and curative health care and health education to women. In places where health facilities and practitioners are relatively more accessible, and large numbers of women can be organized (as SEWA has done in Gujarat), efforts encompass health insurance schemes and maternity benefits. 17. Taking this into consideration, the project has made provisions to assist women to reduce the burden of ill-health in order that they can benefit fully from the economic activities. Where women members of Self-Help Groups express basic health care as a priority need, and there are gaps in the availability of basic public health services, the project provides for an appropriate local NGO to train selected women volunteers in basic health care. It is anticipated that about 60
 -161- Annex 10 percent of SHGs would opt for a strategy to address the health of their communities. As the SHGs grow in strength, their ability to lobby the health system for an improved village-level health care would increase. 18. The health volunteer would be a woman selected by the group in consultation with the wider community. Once trained, she would (a) help to disseminate information on health related issues and promote preventive health care; (b) help group members and other women in the village to access the formal health system or private health facilities, with a focus on women and child health; and (c) where necessary, provide simple basic health care, such as first aid or oral rehydration salts. The project would also provide health education materials, a simple basic kit of equipment and supplies to the trainee. The contents of the kit would be in keeping with practices approved by the state Health Department for primary health care workers. 19. A stepwise approach is envisaged with regard to the activities of the health worker. After training, the focus of her work would initially be with the group. As she gains in confidence and the value of her services is perceived by the wider community, her efforts could extend to the community in response to their demand. Given the already heavy workloads of women, several stakeholders expressed concern that women would only be able to engage in additional income-generating activities if some facilities were available for child care. Although the government has instituted the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program widely, this provides only limited day care to working mothers. In view of this, the project has made provisions for day care to be organized under certain circumstances. The project would assist communities to leverage resources from on-going programs to create community assets which improve the quality of women's daily lives by reducing drudgery and the time taken by routine domestic chores. As an outcome of the International Women's Decade which ended in 1985, GOI requested all states to set up Women's Development Corporations (WDCs) as part of the strategy to switch the focus of women's development initiatives from welfare to development. The WDCs were established as autonomous government undertakings in which the share capital would be contributed by GOI and the state governments in the ratio of 49%:51%. The authorized share capital of the WDCs is generally around Rs. 50 million of which around Rs. 20- 25 million has been paid up in the case of most of the WDCs. 2. Nodal agency and incorporation status. Amongst the WDCs participating in the project there are some variations in terms of their parent department and incorporation status. In Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh, the nodal department for the WDC is the Department of Women and Child Development. In Bihar and Haryana, the WDCs come under the auspices of the Department of Social Welfare whilst in Gujarat, the Department of Industries and Mines is the nodal department. 3 Most of the WDCs (Gujarat, Haryana, Karnataka, and Uttar Pradesh) are incorporated under the Companies Act with the WDC in Madhya Pradesh incorporated under the MP Non- Trading Corporations Rules and Act. The main exception is the Bihar WDC which is registered under the Societies Registration Act. Many of the WDCs are seeking exemption from income tax through classification as non-profit organizations under Section 25 of the Companies Act (or other provisions specific to their states). The activities and operational procedures of the WDCs are controlled by the Boards of Directors and they are not obliged to follow government norms and procedures. 4. Each WDC has a Board of Directors of between 3 and 15 persons. The prescribed composition of the Board between officials and non-officials varies between WDCs. In Gujarat and MP the provisions allow for at least half of the directors to be non-officials, who are generally political appointees. In Karnataka all directors are appointed by the state government. In most cases the Boards have been superseded and are presently composed solely of officials. 5. Only Haryana and Gujarat WDCs have their own district managers or field officers with limited supporting staff. The other WDCs function at the district level through the staff of other departments, who are generally paid an additional small stipend. 6. The principal role of the WDCs is to promote the economic development of women through: (a) facilitating access to training and entrepreneurship development; (b) helping women entrepreneurs to gain access to credit available under various bankable schemes through sanctioning women's applications, and through the provision of capital subsidy or margin money

Assistance is provided to all women, rural and urban, although some schemes which the WDCs implement are targeted at women below the poverty line. This has resulted in a lack of continuity in the strategies adopted to achieve the aims and objectives. In particular, they lack a field structure preventing them from having the direct contact with their client group required to effectively implement programs and to gain a sound appreciation of the needs and priorities of women which they are expected to address. (c) Weak management procedures. Inadequate attention has been paid to establishing effective management procedures for the WDCs. As a result, accounting systems, auditing and planning procedures and monitoring and evaluation systems are deficient. (d) Lack of follow-up support to women entrepreneurs. The WDCs have lacked the resources to provide any back-up support to the self-employment activities they have been instrumental in promoting. 9. Two recent appraisals of the role of the WDCs6 commissioned by DWCD and DANIDA have supported the need to strengthen the WDCs to enable them to be more effective promoters of women's economic development. They have concluded that it is essential for the WDCs to exist and to be strengthened in order to be able to more effectively champion the cause of the all round development of women. These studies have highlighted the following points: (a) Strengthening the organizational structure and clarifying the role of the WDCs would facilitate their efforts for the enhancement of women's economic status; (b) WDCs should play a promotional, catalytic and coordinating role; (c) While WDCs should aim to serve all women, priority should be on reaching rural and urban poor women; (d) WDCs should widen their horizons and become more involved in the overall socio-economic advancement of women including playing a greater advocacy role; (e) WDCs should be provided with adequate budgetary support to cover their promotional activities; 6/ Appraisal of Women's Development Corporations; Women's Development Division, Nationai Institute of Public Cooperation and Child Development, September 1989 Role of Women's Development Corporations; Sarojini Kumtakar, Council for Social Development, January 1994

 -20 1- Annex 12 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT TRAINING Introduction 1. In order to support project activities in each state, a comprehensive training program would be implemented to upgrade the skills of WDCs, NGOs, SHGs, lending institutions and line departments in a variety of areas. It is expected that training needs would evolve during the project in a manner corresponding to the evolution of SHGs and their activities. The major phases currently envisaged in the project are: (a) pre-project, (b) project start-up, (c) project build-up, and (d) stabilization (see Annex 16). I In the pre-project phase, the emphasis would be on appointment of key staff in the WDCs at state and district levels, and on working out common approaches for several sub-components of the project including training, communications, and monitoring and evaluation. * In the start-up phase, the focus of activity would be on the establishment of SHGs capable of managing savings and credit operations. During this phase the capacities of WVDCs and NGOs to form and support SHGs would be developed, and institutional arrangements for the project would be worked out in detail. Communications activities focussed on whole village communities would help to build a supportive environment for the project. * In the build-up phase, the institutional capacity to manage the project would be greatly strengthened, including that of support agencies such as banks, line departments and technical resource agencies. During this phase, linkages between SHGs and lending institutions would be developed in order to ensure women's continued access to credit. * The stabilization phase is characterised by increasing involvement of SHGs in income generating activities, through provision of skills training, design assistance, technology and market linkages. In addition, women's access to better health and drudgery reducing technologies would be enhanced, and community assets created, which would call for additional training of SHGs and project implementors in the social aspects related to the project. 2. Training activities in each phase would build on those in the previous phase with the help of training needs assessments (TNAs), overseen by the Training Coordinator of the WDC, and on feedback from the monitoring and evaluation system. The TNAs would be conducted
 -202- Annex 12 periodically to: (a) identify the training needs of staff at all levels by functional groups; (b) match available training resources with identified needs, and specify gaps in training resources in each state. These steps would lead to the preparation of a training plan and appropriate training programs for the next phase of the project. Both the TNAs and the M&E system would provide information to evaluate previous training efforts, which would be used to improve subsequent training. Contents of Training Component 3. To coordinate the diverse activities of the project, the monitoring and evaluation system would need a computerized project management system, as well as a management information system (CPM/MIS). Given the innovative nature of the project, and the need to benefit from implementation experience, the CPM/MIS system is essential for effective concurrent monitoring and evaluation. In addition, an impact evaluation of the overall project on poverty reduction, as well as other socio-economic indicators, must be carried out to assess whether such programs have desirable impacts both at the participant level and the society level. The main objective is to assess the project's self sustainability and cost effectiveness as well as evaluate it's effects on poverty reduction and empowerment. In particular the M&E will: * Assess the group sustainability, financial viability, outreach, and institutional viability of the program. * Provide feed-back to relevant project affiliates that is based on process monitoring and evaluation. * Assess via impact evaluations the poverty reduction effects as well as effects on other socio-economic indicators of the project. 2. Participatory methods would be promoted so that SHG members are assisted to assess their own progress in tracking the impacts of their own actions in the family and community. Sponsoring NGOs would facilitate the SHGs in these processes. In addition, a household survey will be administered on a sample of households to evaluate the above-mentioned impacts of the project. Conceptual Outline 3. Five modules have been proposed to provide guidance on the selection of indicators for different components of the project. They provide a guideline for developing the detailed framework for M&E of the project. 4. Module 1: Group Formation, Activities and Outreach. The objective of this module is to assess formation of stable, viable and self-reliant SHGs. This includes measures of group dynamics such as internal cohesion and homogeneity, equity and savings and loans behavior. Other qualitative indicators such as relationship among members, group functioning, rotation of leadership, etc., would also be measured.
 -218- Annex 14 5. Module 2: Financial Sustainability. Achieving financial sustainability is important to demonstrate the program's independence from donor funds for its activities. The CPM/MIS would track the progress made towards financial sustainability. Essentially, the system would continuously track the income and expenses of the program at the group, cluster/NGO level, and check whether they are moving towards balancing each other. There are several indicators that provide useful information on the bottleneck(s) towards achieving financial sustainability. All indicators must be evaluated at the group level. They may also be evaluated at the cluster/federation level should financial links evolve for clusters/federations. 6. Indicators for this module would include measures of savings and loan process, income and expenses and other variables. Estimates would also be generated of portfolio at risk rate, loan loss rate, operating costs as a percent of portfolio, total costs as a percent of portfolio, average loan size/cost per loan, percent of loans with past due amounts, amount of liquid funds as a percent of loan portfolio, and trends in distribution of loan use. In addition, growth indicators for tracking progress would be measured. Most of the information pertaining to savings, loans, repayment, and interest rates in this module would be gathered from the account books of individual members in the group which would be aggregated for the group in a ledger book. This aggregation would be facilitated by NGOs initially, and as the groups mature, the leaders of the groups would take over the task. The expenses and costs figures would be kept by the NGOs and frequently updated to reflect accurate information. Processing of information at the group level would also be facilitated, so that groups would be able to assess their progress and understand and act on the components that are not performing as desired. 7. Module 3: Institutional Viability. The objective of this module is to assess the institutional viability of the program at all levels, i.e., groups, clusters, local NGOs, district level organizations, state WDCs, credit and financial institutions. Indicators would include measures of group level effectiveness, NGO staff productivity, institutional efficiency (district and state level) and institutional durability. 8. Module 4: Empowerment. Choice of variables for this module would be participatory in order that the measures and indicators reflect the client/group members' perceptions of empowerment. The baseline survey would include these measures to facilitate assessment of changes that may have occurred due to project participation. A few key variables for assessment of empowerment are suggested for evaluation vis-a-vis self, family and community. These include self-related variables and social family/community variables. The information on the above variables would be collected via in-depth interviews. Participatory methods of self- assessment are very important for the groups since this will enable their process of empowerment. Since self-help groups inculcate positive development values like self-respect and dignity, these types of impacts are also best captured in detailed case analyses. 9. Module 5: Impact Assessment. Client, household and intra-household impact of project participation would be evaluated based on household surveys of targeted samples. A household survey questionnaire would be developed to capture baseline information, as well as follow-up
 -219- Annex 14 surveys on all key variables to assess household and intra-household impacts in consumption and production and the poverty reduction effects of the program. A few key variables would be, among others, patterns of income spending on food, clothing, housing, health, etc., by the client on herself and her family; asset accumulation; income growth; access to factors of production; and time use profiles. Since impact is assessed by looking at changes before and after project experience, care would be taken to control for factors outside the purview of this project that could influence these measures. Participatory impact assessments, utilizing suitable methodologies, would also measure these impacts.  -230- Annex 15 2. Status of Women. The status of women in tribal societies is generally more equitable than that of women in non-tribal communities, as demonstrated by the more favorable sex ratio among tribal people: 977 females per 1000 males for tribal India as a whole, compared to 927 females per 1000 males in the non-tribal population. However, the poverty, isolation of tribal communities, and low level of literacy among tribal women contributes to their overall disadvantage. High female work participation rates among tribal groups is a reflection of greater equity - but also of the greater burden faced by women who are often solely responsible for the well-being of their households on account of the out-migration of male members, and may have large households to manage including numerous children. Poor access to social services such as child care facilities, health care and family planning services, and schooling for children, contribute to this situation. 3. Socio-Economic Characteristics. The tribal districts in the project are characterized by widely differing socio-economic, cultural and agro-climatic features. Table ...1 shows the percentage of females among the tribal populations of each district who were literate at the time of the 1981 Census; the percentage of tribal women participating in the labor force; and the percentage of all tribal workers (male and female) who were in the primary sector. Although these data are based on the 1981 census, they give an indication of the poor status of tribal women in the project districts, and permit some inter-district and inter-state comparisons. While the percentage of literate females is likely to have increased since 1981 (by about 10 percentage points at most in any district), changes in the other two parameters have probably been marginal. 4. In general, work participation among tribal communities, and especially among tribal women, is higher than among non-tribal counterparts. Among tribal groups, work was traditionally related to community ownership of the means of production and so was usually undertaken collectively. In most areas, tribal people traditionally did not depend entirely on agriculture but engaged also in collection of forest produce, hunting, craft-making, and so on. This also meant that tribal workers had a range of skills, such as those for cultivation, animal-skinning, woodwork, domestic arts, etc. However, many tribes in the central part of the country (Bihar and Madhya Pradesh) have increasingly adopted the culture of non-tribal peasant communities. Dependence on agriculture has increased as tribal people have been alienated from forests, and gradual assimilation into non-tribal ways of life has eroded the traditional skill base. The project's approach of forming women's Self-Help Groups has special significance in these contexts, as working collectively and engaging in multiple occupations are integral aspects of tribal culture. The provision of literacy to tribal women and improving market linkages for tribal produce are also important to improving the quality of tribal people's lives. 5. The agro-climatic features of tribal areas in the project districts also vary remarkably. The Chotanagpur plateau of south Bihar is characterized by red clay soils upland and fertile lower lands and valleys, with an overall low percentage of irrigated land. About 90 percent of people in these areas are engaged in agriculture, and about 60 percent of land holdings are under one hectare. Rice or maize is the staple crop, vegetable gardening is common, and small animals are an important source of cash income, especially for women. Small farmers supplement their income through wage labor or selling forest produce, but there are also groups which are largely dependent for their
 -231- Annex 15 livelihoods on the collection and sale of minor forest produce. The situation in the tribal district of Panchmahals in Gujarat is somewhat the reverse -- greater dependence on forest collection and wage labor among the tribals. In some other areas of Gujarat there is an emphasis on craft. In Karnataka, tribal people in the project districts are largely engaged as agricultural labor, with some involved in sericulture on their own small holdings, and other groups being mainly pastoralists. 6. Spatial Distribution. Tribal populations usually live clustered in specific blocks and villages. The higher the proportion of tribal people in a district's rural population, the wider spread are tribal habitations. For example, in the most highly tribal of the project districts (Ranchi in Bihar, Bharuch and Panchmahals in Gujarat, and Betul in Madhya Pradesh), almost all blocks of the district have significant proportions of tribal people, though the actual percentages may vary widely, as seen in Table .1. A large number of villages in these districts and blocks would have tribal residents. On the other hand, districts with lower concentrations (e.g., below 20 percent of their total rural populations) have only a few blocks containing significant tribal populations; and these people would be living clustered in a few villages. In such situations, the tribal population is often quite isolated, living in small villages or hamlets with poor access and with limited and eroding resource bases. 7. Infrastructure. Areas inhabited by tribal people are less well developed in terms of infrastructure such as roads, markets, schools, health centres, and so on. Due to their physical isolation and lack of resources, public systems and facilities are usually understaffed and may offer virtually no services. As a result, tribal people have less choice of economic activities, lower access to technology, lower incomes, and poorer social indicators than the general population. These factors have an important bearing on the project, and linkages between project activities will be stronger and greater effort will be spent on improving women's access to services in both the economic and social spheres. The project proposes to harness the Tribal Sub-Plans (TSP) in each state and the resources provided therein to strengthen the necessary linkages. For this purpose, the social assessments (see Section II below) have included a review of the local tribal area sub-plans, and have been followed by the development of specific action plans for each tribal district. 8. Tribal Institutions. Tribal areas are also characterized by the existence of special institutions - both traditional and "modern" ones created by the government. In the former category are moneylenders who exercise a strong hold over poor tribal families. Legislation has not succeeded in curbing some exploitative practices of moneylenders, such as taking over lands or bonding labor. Access to public lending institutions is constrained by tribal people's lack of awareness of facilities, low educational levels constraining abilities to "negotiate" fornal systems, and physical distance from facilities. In addition, tribal people may be doubly exploited by unscrupulous traders who charge high prices for goods brought from outside the area, while offering very low prices for forest and other produce offered in exchange by the tribal people. The project's approaches of encouraging thrift, credit rotation from among women's own savings, and improved marketing could help to reduce some of these dependencies and the resultant problems. Amongst the "modem" tribal institutions are Tribal (or SC/ST) Cooperative Marketing Federations and Large Area Multipurpose Societies (LAMPS) which encompass primary cooperatives and were
 -232- Annex 15 specifically established for tribal areas. The main functions of the LAMPS are to provide credit to members for agricultural inputs, including fertilizers, and to purchase produce from farmers at fair prices on behalf of various apex organizations. In some cases the LAMPS operate PDS centers to provide basic commodities to tribal people. 9. Tribal Sub Plans. This project goes beyond the approach of the Tribal Sub Plans in some significant ways, and builds on institutions which benefit tribal people. A working group set up in connection with the preparation of the Eighth Five Year Plan found a lack of impact of TSP investments and ascribed this to a lack of attention to the "felt needs" of tribal people. In contrast, this project will base its interventions on extensive consultations with tribal people, especially women. Through such consultations, and the development of women's capacities to participate further in implementation, the project will focus on the expressed needs and preferences of tribal women and implement activities which are culturally acceptable to them. In addition, the project aims to create sustainable livelihoods through the formation of thrift and credit groups and the introduction and/or enhancement of viable income-generating activities, supported by the necessary "forward and backward" linkages. Thus, the project is also in tune with several principles espoused by the Eighth Plan, which are likely to continue in the Ninth Plan, for the development of tribal peoples: decentralized planning, involving people and non-governmental agencies; local employment creation; poverty reduction; improving education, health and other social amenities; and investment for asset creation. It. The Project's Approach to to Planning for Tribal Women 10. A Tribal Status Paper and Tribal Development Plans are being prepared for each district in the project which has a significant tribal population, and would be ready by negotiations. The Tribal Status Paper collates key information on tribal people in the project areas in order to provide an analytical base for planning meaningful interventions to improve the economic and social status of tribal women. The Tribal Development Plans (TDPs) are aimed at ensuring that tribal women in the project areas participate in project activities, that their capacities to do so are developed, and that they receive economic and social benefits under the project. The Status Papers and TDPs are based on social assessments which have been undertaken to understand first hand the socio- economic situation of tribal women and to participatively plan interventions which can be implemented within the project framework and are culturally acceptable to them. The assessments would: a) collate demographic information on the tribal populations of the proposed project districts identifying block/village concentrations of tribal people; b) compile relevant social and economic data on the main tribal groups from secondary sources; focusing attention on the livelihoods, economic roles and work patterns of women, their access to major resources, income levels, literacy, health status, community organizations and other relevant issues, and analyzing and reporting the information in a manner that is useful for project implementation;
 -233- Annex 15 c) collect information on available infrastructure and government programs which are being implemented for tribal people in the project districts, including their coverage and effectiveness and resources available under the local Tribal Sub Plans; d) collect information from the major NGOs in the project districts on their program efforts with tribal people, and on their views of the success or failure of these, the priority needs of the tribal population, and the constraints in addressing them; e) carry out participatory assessments, including focus group discussions and in-depth interviews, with tribal people, especially women, to understand their situations, identify their priority needs and preferences for economic and social interventions which can be made within the scope of the project, and determine how the project might address these; in some instances village case studies will be prepared; and f) refine and organize these suggestions into strategies and specific interventions to be undertaken to address the key needs of tribal women in the project areas, preparing clear action plans for the project. 11. The TDPs would identify the specific objectives to be achieved and strategies to be followed, the proposed activities, implementation arrangements, and actions to monitor the project in tribal areas. They would include a set of matrices on the following: * ProjectActivities: listing Project Objectives, Development Actions to be taken under the project, and Implementing Agency/agencies; this matrix identifies actions under sub-sections on, for example, Group Formation, Thrift and Credit, Production/Income- Generation, Social Development, Training, and Coordination; * Organization and Management: giving the Implementing Agency, its Members and their Functions; the agencies include SHGs, NGOs, local (tribal) community organizations, line departments, and the Women's Development Corporation; * Monitoring and Evaluation: specifying the monitoring Action to be taken, the Agency, and how the Action is to be carried out. III. Strategies and Interventions for Tribal Women 12. From the information gathered on the situations of tribal areas in the project districts, and through the project's approach to planning for tribal women, an overall strategy and a number of specific interventions have been identified for tribal populations. 13. Project Strategy. The overall strategy of the project would be as successful among tribal communities as among non-tribal groups. The project's approach of forming women's Self-Help
 -234- Annex 15 Groups, motivating members to save and rotate their savings amongst themselves, obtain first cash credit and then term loans from banks, and avail of project provided skills training, inputs and linkages, is appropriate to tribal women on account of the poverty and poor resource base of tribal areas, and it is supported by favorable cultural norms prevailing among tribal people. 14. In the context of the approach of this project, that of forming village-level Self-Help Groups through the intermediation of NGOs, the spatial distribution of tribal people has particular significance. First, to overcome the physical isolation of tribal people and penetrate prevailing cultural barriers, it will be necessary to involve NGOs that have experience of working with tribal people, preferably in the same areas or at least with the same or similar tribal groups, and/or NGOs who are willing to work amongst these groups. NGOs working in districts such as Ranchi (Bihar) or Panchmahals (Gujarat) which are highly tribal are likely to have the capability to work with tribal people. In other districts, such as Hoshangabad or Dewas (Madhya Pradesh) or the four project districts in Kamataka, there may be some NGOs with relevant experience, and others without. In these cases, judicious selection of NGOs will be called for in order to ensure that the project reaches some tribal women. 15. Second, an understanding of the livelihood patterns (including occupations, resource base, income, and migratory habits) of the tribal people in each district (or sub-district area) is critical to planning project activities - thrift and credit, income generation, as well as social development - in ways which are economically and culturally relevant to the tribal group. However, the poorer infrastructure and difficult conditions of tribal areas suggest that more intensive efforts will be required to achieve effective results. In this regard, the selection of strong, hard-working NGOs is critical. Through their intermediation between the tribal communities and mainstream institutions, such as banks and line departments, to ensure the provision of improved services, some major constraints faced by tribal people could be removed, or at least reduced. Furthermore, the approach of the project to provide group members functional literacy and communities with assets, basic health care and child care could fill major gaps that persist in social services in tribal areas. 16. Specific Interventions. Among specific interventions, the following have been identified as most likely to be implemented among tribal communities in the project: * Functional literacy for all group members, on account of the low levels of literacy prevailing among tribal women * Consolidation of water resources through group and individual action to improve drinking water supplies as well as soil moisture for land-based activities; creation of drinking water facilities for communities and education on maintaining clean water sources, because tribal areas usually have either extreme water scarcity or shallow sources of water * Enhancing productivity of homestead land for own consumption and market production, through soil improvement, diversification of crops (vegetables, legumes, fruit trees) and improved cropping practices, building on land availability and ownership in tribal areas
 -235- Annex 15 * Improving small animal rearing and management as a primary or secondary income- generating activity * Enhancing home-based processing of agricultural and forest products * Improving designs, product quality, and productive efficiency among craftspersons and artisans, along with better marketing of craft products * Basic health care training, because the gap in health services in tribal areas is large; elements of traditional health care would be introduced by involving specialized NGOs who have developed capability in this field * Community organized 'mini' child care centres, particularly where tribal women work at some distance from homes or live in secluded hamlets; these may be needed even in areas where ICDS is operational because of the low coverage afforded by ICDS. 17. Monitoring and Evaluation. Baseline surveys conducted before project launch will capture relevant information on the characteristics of tribal women involved in the project. The M&E component of the project would be appropriately designed to reflect any specific project inputs in tribal areas which result from the assessments of tribal women's status and Tribal Development Plans. In districts where SHGs consist mainly of tribal women, the M&E component would compare the progress of tribal groups to that of other groups, and suitably modify project inputs, if necessary.

B. PROJECT SUPERVISION 3. Supervision Strategy. The project is by nature complex and will require intensive management, monitoring and supervision. The creation of monitoring and evaluation capability within the normal functions of project management in the center as well in the states would be an important management tool to facilitate successful implementation. To coordinate the diverse activities of the project, the monitoring and evaluation system would include a computerized project management system, as well as a management information system (CPM-MIS) to fully benefit from implementation experience, and to enable effective planning, monitoring and supervision. (See Annex 14 for more information on the proposed M&E system for the project).
 -242- Annex 16 Other important inputs towards supervision of the project would include: the use of development indicators; a system of quarterly and annual reports; planning/review workshops at the national, state and district levels; annual action plans and budgets; special reports /studies on specific activities; and a mid-term review. Complimentary use of these inputs with mandatory supervision wok would be the key element of the proposed supervision strategy. 4. Supervision Plans and Responsibilities. Given the decentralized nature and multi-state structure of the project, responsibility for supervising the project would be shared between a number of agencies. Each agency with supervision responsibility would first prepare its own plan highlighting areas of responsibilities/focus. These plans would then be used to develop an overall annual plan to maximize coordination and synergy. The main agencies involved in supervision work would include: (a) Central Project Support Unit (CPSU). The CPSU would monitor project's progress and participate in the supervision work with a special emphasis on overseeing proposed actions for strengthening of implementation capacity of WDCs. More specifically CPSU would supervise:: (a) activities to build the capacities of project implementors, (b) information exchange amongst the state WDCs and other implementing agencies, and between them and other national and international agencies with relevant expertise and experience; and (c) coordinate monitoring and evaluation activities. To facilitate information exchange across states, the CPSU would propose and organize fora for information sharing. The CPSU would also commission special studies/consultancies to analyze the progress of specific aspects of the project and share this information with the participating agencies as well as use the findings as inputs to its own (and IDA's) supervision work; (b) State Women's Development Corporations (WDC). The state WDCs would be responsible for promoting the project concept, for engaging NGOs to implement the project at the field level, and for guiding and monitoring them, and for overall coordination and supervision of project implementation in the state. The WDCs would be responsible for preparing annual and quarterly action plans and budgets, quarterly and annual progress reports, and reimbursement claims for submission to the CPSU/DWCD. For this work they would seek assistance from consultants, especially to assess NGOs' training activities, and activities related to credit and finance. The WDCs would interact with the CPSU to indicate their specific needs by way of special studies to be initiated by the center. Feedback from the M&E system would guide the focus of the supervision work on an on-going basis; (c) Other Agencies. Project supervision would benefit from the input provided by participating NGOs. While operating as the key agencies forming SHGs and interacting with communities at the grassroots levels, NGOs would assist in supervision by providing timely feedback to WDCs on the performance of SHGs
 -243- Annex 16 in project activities, and on the views of SHG members. In addition, the project's supervision work would benefit from close interaction between DWCD, IDA, IFAD and the Inter-Agency Working Group (IAWG) on Gender and Development, which meets in Delhi regularly and includes representatives of UN, multilateral and bilateral agencies. Some of the activities considered by the IAWG in support of project supervision include: (a) establishment of an advisory or resource group for periodic sharing of experiences; (b) involvement in monitoring and evaluating the project; and (c) advocacy and policy dialogue with GOI on the basis of "lessons learned" from the project. DWCD and WDCs would be encouraged to liaise closely with inmplementors of bilateral women's projects to ensure exchange of information and experiences. In addition, wherever appropriate, representatives from bilateral agencies with relevant experience would be invited to participate in IDA supervision missions or undertake review/studies on specific subjects of generic interest to all concerned. (d) IDA S3peiiqon. The core of IDA's supervision work would be the six-monthly supervision missions. IDA would also have the responsibility to supervise the project on behalf of IFAD but representative would join mission at regular intervals. Important inputs for IDA missions would be the quarterly and annual progress reports to be produced by WDCs and annual synthesis report on the overall progress of the project to be produced by CPSU. Annex 16, Attachment I provides a provisional plan for IDA's supervision work. The key elements of this plan would be: (i) Mission Frequency. Bank supervision missions will visit the project approximately every six months. If the project is launched in March 1997, the first supervision mission following project launch workshop would be around September 1997. However, due to the innovative nature of the project, during the initial two years of the project it is anticipated that during the initial years additional short missions would be required to facilitate implementation and adoption of IDA's guidelines for procurement, disbursement and reporting. (ii) Composition of the Mission. The missions will be lead by the Bank Task Manager, and will include, as appropriate at the time, specialists in institutional development, M&E, training, communications, social, economic, financial, and procurement issues. Annex 16 Attachment 2 provides an estimated IDA supervision input over the duration of the project. This attachment also lists the requirements taken n to account in developing this list. (iii) Project Activities linked with Missions. During one of the supervision missions each year, a workshop will be held with all key project implementation agencies to review project progress in a participatory manner. The supervision mission will be informed by discussions of experience on the ground, constraints encountered, and needs expressed by
 -244- Annex 16 the project stakeholders for project redesign. These annual workshops may also be linked with the annual work plans and budgets prepared by the WDCs and CPSU. Part C: Reporting and Reviews 3. Reporting. The main building blocks for the reporting system of the project would be the quarterly and annual progress reports to be produced by WDCs and CPSU with the help of their respective M&E agencies. The annual report on the overall progress of the project to be produced by CPSU would synthesize the findings of the reports submitted by the states and draw lessons as appropriate for sharing with the main implementing agencies. The proposed Table of Contents of the progress reports is given in Annex 16, Attachment I, which would finalized in discussion with the implementing agencies. The proposed structure of the reports allows the implementing agencies to provide: (i) an overview of progress and status of performance indicators; (ii) information on the progress by category of expenditures; (iii) information on project expenditure in relation to budget for each quarter and fiscal year; (iv) information on the financial management; and (v) information on compliance with project's legal covenants. 4. The Mid-Term Review. Approximately halfway through the project period a mid-term review of the project progress would be carried out jointly by GOI and IDA. The CPSU and all implementing agencies in the participating states, would submit progress reports to IDA for this review. Thus, if the project is launched in early 1997, this would be approximately in September 1999. The principal aim of the mid-term review would be to determine whether there are any major issues or problems in the project which necessitate rethinking the original project design and making mid-course corrections. Feedback from the CPM/MIS will be utilized in this process. It may also be used for a preliminary impact assessment of the project. A mid-term review report will be submitted to IDA and discussed with the subsequent supervision mission. It would highlight any major problems, issues, bottlenecks or delays in project execution, and discuss the prospects for resolving them and completing the project on time.

National Competitive Bidding (NCB) would be used for the procurement of computers and major items of office equipment where they can be bulked together. This only applies to the start-up phase of the project in each state. National Competitive Bidding requires: (i) publication of Invitation for Bid (IFB) in newspapers with wide circulation within the country; (ii) use of the Bank's standard bidding documents; (iii) sale of bidding documents to start only after publication of the IFB; (iv) bidding period 30-60 days from the date of the start of sale of bidding documents; and (v) single envelop system for submission of bids. 2. The following steps are to be followed: (i) notification/advertising; (ii) issue of bidding documents; (iii) submission of bids; (iv) public opening of bids; (v) evaluation of bids; (vi) award in favor of lowest evaluated bidder who is determined to be qualified to perform the contract satisfactorily; and (vii) no negotiations. The notification/advertisement and evaluation of bids report would be reviewed by IDA. 3. Prior review would be required for all contracts of US$100, 000 and above and would take place at the following stages: (i) invitation to bid; (ii) bidding documents; (iii) bid evaluation report; and (iv) final contracts. 4. The schedule of the critical steps for national competitive bidding suggests about 34 weeks would normally be required from preparation of the specifications and bidding documents to the delivery date. Accordingly, to ensure that required equipment and goods are on hand to start the work program for a fiscal year that begins on April 1, procurement activities should normally begin by the preceding August 15. National Shopping 5. National shopping procedures would be used to procure vehicles, office and other equipment, furniture and materials in individual contracts not to exceed US$20, 000. Rate contracts of the Directorate General of Supplies and Disposals (DGS&D), New Delhi, would only be acceptable as a substitute for procurement under national shopping. State rate contracts would not be acceptable but may feature as one of the quotations under the standard national shopping procedures. 6. The essential elements of national shopping are: (i) clear description and quantity of the item(s), as well as a specified delivery date; (ii) price quotations obtained from several suppliers,
 -250- Annex 17 usually at least three to ensure competitive prices; (iii) evaluation of quotations to follow sound public/private sector practices of the purchaser; and (iv) the purchase order placed with the lowest evaluated supplier by suitably incorporating the terms of the accepted offer. Further negotiations are not permitted after the lowest qualifying quotation has been evaluated. 7. All documents associated with the purchase of goods under national shopping procedures would be subject to selective post-review by visiting missions. Such reviews would concentrate on the procedures used and the competitiveness of prices paid and physical inspections of the relevant items. 8. The schedule of the critical steps for national shopping suggests about 10 weeks would normally be required from the preparation of the initial specifications to the delivery date. Accordingly, to ensure that required equipment and goods are on hand to start the work program for a fiscal year that begins on April 1, procurement activities should normally begin by the preceding January 15. Both NGOs and consulting services would be procured in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers. Prior review is required by IDA for: (i) Terms of Reference regardless of value; (ii) all single source selection of consulting firm; (iii) all consultant contracts for assignment of a critical nature, regardless of value; and (iv) contracts for consultancy services valued at equivalent of US$100,000 and above for consulting firms and US$50,000 and above for individuals. For contracts falling within the thresholds, prior review would be at the following stages: (i) Terms of Reference; (ii) shortlist: (iii) documents containing the Letter of Invitation, Supplementary Information to Consultants and Conditions of Contract; (iv) Evaluation Report of the technical proposals; (v) negotiated draft contract (with a copy of the winning proposal) before signing of the contract; and (vi) conformed signed copy of the final contract required in order to authorise disbursement against the contract.

 -257- Annex 18 INDIA RURAL WOMEN'S DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT PROJECT FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. Financial Analysis 1. The resource base in the project areas would enable a wide range of income generating activities to be undertaken by the women. Since the women will be responsible for selecting activities which are appropriate to their circumstances, only an indication of the activities likely to feature in the lending program can be given. Financial models for a range of on-farm and non- farmn activities have been prepared and are presented in Tables I to 23 for on-farm activities covering crop production (paddy, wheat, sorghum, pulses, sunflower and chillies); horticulture (vegetable production, banana, annual flowers, vegetable seedling production and fruit tree nursery); livestock (goat rearing, kid and lamb fattening) and a range of production, trade and services non-farm activities. The physical and financial parameters used in the models will vary across the participating states and hence the financial models can only give a broad indication of the expected financial returns. Many of the crop production activities represent up-grading of existing technology through the use of improved varieties and higher amounts of fertilizer. The horticulture activities represent ways of increasing the returns to small areas of land through focusing on high value crops which women are ideally suited to manage. Small livestock activities would be undertaken in small units (e.g. 3 lambs or 5 kids) as supplementary income earning activities. Non-farm activities selected mainly represent low investment, high turnover trading and service activities. 2. The results of the financial analysis of these activities are summarized in Table 24 in terms of incremental net income, return per manday and incremental benefit: cost ratio. Incremental net incomes are variable as they cover both supplementary and full-time activities but generally exceed Rs. 4,000 per annum. Return per manday is in excess of Rs. 30 with many activities yielding returns of between Rs. 50 and 80/day. This compares with the average wage for women in agricultural labor of around Rs. 15-20 per day with the exception of Haryana where higher rates prevail. The incremental benefit:cost ratios are in excess of 1.5. B. Economic Analysis Approach 3. Given the multi-faceted nature of the project, many of the benefits, particularly those relating to social change, cannot readily be quantified. The quantifiable benefits relate to the project's objective to increase women's economic independence through access to credit, training and other technical support services to increase their involvement in income generating activities. Even here, given the flexibility in the credit mechanism and the freedom of choice to be exercised by the women in the selection of activities, the economic analysis of the project requires more than the usual number of assumptions and therefore a high degree of approximation. The major uncertainties concern loan uptake, the proportion of loans used for
 -258- Annex 18 social purposes, the mix of activities financed, and the extent to which project loans are replacing existing more expensive sources of credit from the informal sector and hence are not generating incremental economic benefits. 4. Economic prices and costs. Economic import parity prices have been calculated based on the World Bank Quarterly Review of Commodity Markets dated August 1996. World market prices for internationally traded commodities are based on price projections for the year 2000 in constant 1996 prices. Farmgate equivalent import parity prices have been calculated for rice, wheat, sorghum, urea, phosphate and potash (Table 25). India is approaching self-sufficiency in rice and wheat. However, India's high population growth (2.2% per year), as well as the high income elasticity of demand for rice and other cerealsl justifies considering these commodities as import substitutes. All other commodities have been considered as non-traded on the international market. Their financial prices (at constant June 1996 prices) have been adjusted to economic prices using a SCF of 0.9. 5. Women in the rural areas are not able to find employment throughout the year and face considerable underemployment or unemployment for at least 4 months of the year. This has been reflected in the derivation of shadow wage rates for female labour. For seasonal agricultural activities, it has been assumed that the requirement for labour coincides with times when women are able to find employment and the financial wage rate of INR 20 per day has been adjusted by the SCF to derive a shadow wage of INR 18/day. For livestock and non-farm activities which are undertaken on a year-round basis, a factor of 0.66 has been applied to the financial wage rate, adjusted by the SCF, giving an average shadow rate of female labour of INR 12/day. Financial and economic prices are summarized in Table 26. 6. Methodology To obtain an approximate estimate of the project benefits, a multi-stage approach incorporating various assumptions has been used. Firstly, economic models have been prepared for a range of 23 typical income generating activities taken up by women covering crops, livestock, and non-farm activities. The experience of the lending pattern of some existing self-help groups indicates that crop and livestock loans are expected to represent around 85% of lending and non-farm activities around 15%. On this basis, a weighted average net incremental benefit and net incremental cost over the range of activities was derived. A weighted average unit investment requirement was similarly calculated for the representative range of activities giving an average unit investment of Rs. 4,100. This was used to derive the number of activities which could be financed each year with the funds available for investment. For crop activities, a hectare has been used as the unit of investment but women are likely to borrow for smaller areas and hence the average loan size would be less. 7. A number of assumptions have been used to indicate the volume of lending from the groups each year which is likely to generate incremental economic benefits. The assumptions used in the base case are as follows: (a) the quantum of bank credit accessed by an SHG increases in relation to the equity base of the group and an increasing loan:savings ratio to reach around Rs. 100,000 by the fifth year of a group's existence (see Annex 7, Attachment 2); (b) the percentage of funds available to the group which are lent out each year increases from 90% to
 -259- Annex 18 95% by the fourth year of the group's operations; (c) the average rotation of investment funds is initially twice per year when very short term consumption loans dominate the lending program (some groups achieve up to four times), but reduces to 1.5 times as more loans are given for productive purposes; (d) the percentage of funds lent out which generate incremental economic benefits increases from 15% to 40% by the fourth year of operation - analysis of existing SHGs indicates that initially the percentage of lending for consumption/social purposes ranges from 20%-70% but reduces over time whilst in the early stages a high proportion of loans for productive purposes replace other more expensive sources of credit; (e) most of the lending initially is for short term activities and many activities will initially require repeat loans to sustain the activity - it is assumed that on average it will take three years for activities to become self-financing; 8. All the project costs for support for income generating activities have been included in the analysis whilst 50% of the other support costs (capacity building of the SHGs and intervenors and project management costs) are assumed to have a direct impact on the involvement of women in income generating activities. The costs of the social programs have been excluded. Economic costs have been estimated by deducting taxes and multiplying the financial base costs plus physical contingencies by the SCF of 0.9. Economic Results 9. Overall project returns Analysed over ten years, the economic rate of return is estimated to be 25% and the NPV at the opportunity cost of capital of 12% is estimated to be Rs. 319 million (US$ 7.4 million) as shown in Table 27. 10. Sensitivity analysis A number of scenarios were tested to establish the economic viability of the project. The results are presented below: EIRR (%) NPV Rs. million Base case 25 335 Benefits decrease by 10% 12 (10) Activity costs increase by 10% 15 70 Support costs increase by 10% 23 288 Max. 50% of funds generate increm econ benefits 26 367 Max 30% of funds generate increm econ benefits 21 196 1 year lag in investment activities 19 100 11. Switching values indicate that the project benefits could decrease by 10% for the NPV to fall to zero whilst project activity costs could increase by 13%. The percentage of funds generating incremental economic benefits could fall to 20%. This indicates that the project is more sensitive to the performance of the investment activities financed as these impact individually on the cost and benefit streams than to variations in the assumptions on the overall pattern of lending which impact on both costs and benefits simultaneously.

 -262- Annex 18 Public Sector Role and Fiscal Impact 13. Public Sector and Non-governmental Roles. The project designs allocates substantial responsibilities and resources to non-governmental entities and supplies a small amount of supplemental resources directly to government in order to build capacity. Of the total project costs, about US$ 19 million (36 percent) would flow to the SHGs and US$ 25 million (47%) to NGOs, academic institutions and other contracted specialists. Project expenditures flowing to government would comprise about US$ 9.0 million (17% of total project costs) for goods, travel, salaries of incremental staff and operation and maintenance. 14. Cost recovery. Whilst in the initial phase of the program no specific cost recovery measures are proposed, it is intended to examine opportunities for partial recovery of the costs of some services during project implementation. Experience from on-going NGO programs suggests that SHG members are increasingly willing to pay for services which deliver tangible benefits. In this context, the project will promote, on a pilot basis, the formation of clusters and associations of SHGs. This experiment will test the ability of these bodies to take over many of the NGO support services to SHGs and possibly some of the technical support services provided under the project, on a self-financing basis. 15. Fiscal impact. Given the pilot nature of the project, it represents a very small financial burden and the overall impact on the state and/or central government budgets will be negligible. All incremental staff would not be additional to the establishment but would be hired on contract or would come on deputation from government departments where their posts would be frozen. All contracts can be discontinued at the end of the project. The project incorporates a defined exit strategy for intervenors. Support to SHGs by NGOs would be limited to four years. By the end of the project, the mature SHGs would have taken over the responsibility for managing their affairs from the NGOs either on an individual group basis or through the formation of clusters and associations of clusters. Phasing of the process of group formation, however, means that around 60% of the SHGs may be less than four years old by the end of the project period. Whilst some of these may be integrated into clusters and associations for receipt of on-going support, others would still require support directly from the NGOs. The total cost of NGO support outside of the project period would be around Rs. 28 million (US$ 0.8 million) over three years. 16. Sustainability. A major thrust of the project is capacity building of the SHGs so that they are capable of managing their own affairs and are able to further their own social and economic development by virtue of the awareness and linkages established under the project with lending institutions and technical and social support agencies. Most of the SHGs would be linked to the banks and the expected high repayment rates and reduction in the banks' transaction costs should ensure a continuing flow of credit to the groups. In addition, the formation of clusters of SHGs and cluster associations is expected to take place and these, over time, will take over many of the support functions hitherto provided by the NGOs whilst also playing a vital role in the wider replication of the SHG concept. Building the capacity of mature SHGs to promote the formation of additional SHGs not only strengthens the existing groups and furthers
 -263- Annex 18 their sustainability but contributes to a more cost-effective and sustainable approach to the formation of SHGs, with an anticipated reduction in direct NGO support costs of almost 50%.

doc.repnme: India - Rural Women's Development and Empowerment Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Rural Women's Development and Empowerment Project is to strengthen processes that promote economic development of women and create an environment for social change. The specific objectives are to: a) establish women's self-help groups (SHGs); b) sensitize and strengthen the institutional capacity of support agencies to proactively address women's needs; c) increase the incomes of poor women; d) develop linkages between SHGs and lending institutions to ensure women's access to credit financing; and e) improve access to better health care, education and drudgery reduction facilities. The project will pursue its objectives through the following components: a) institutional capacity building for women's development; b) establish support mechanisms for women managed income generating activities; c) establish mechanisms to access social programs and leverage funds for community assets creation; and d) provide effective project management systems.
